Caution: it does seem to start slowly as the film sets up the plot of the young women being disinherited and their greedy sister-in-law preventing their elder brother from endowing them with the funds needed for their station. <br /> <br />Watch for Hugh Laurie's incredibly pained (and outstanding)performance as a serious, quiet man married to a silly woman who never stops talking.  He uses a newspaper as a shield against his wife and mother-in-law's slings and arrows.  Now being a \\"House\\" television series fan, when I re-watch this film, I wish he could let loose on his wife like he does as House! <br /> <br />Even if you don't like Austen novels, you will like this film if you are a fan of films of the 1930s and 1940s.  Why?  Because it is driven by the script and not special effects.  It's about people, and the painful daily choices we must make knowing that love does not always conquer all.   <br /> <br />The soundtrack is outstanding too.  I bought that on CD several years ago and it's one of my favorites.

B000GFLEBI|4.0|Based upon the wonderful, well-written novel \\"Red Dragon\\" by Thomas Harris, this is a superior and chilling thriller. Grim and gripping, it features Edward Norton in the role of troubled, retired FBI agent, Will Graham, who is called back to service in order to track down a bizarre serial killer, known as the \\"Tooth Fairy\\". It appears that Graham has the uncanny ability to get into a killer's mindset and figure out what his next move might be. It is as if he and the killer become one. In his preparation for this, Graham even consults the imprisoned Hannibal Lecter (yes, THE Hannibal Lecter), deliciously played by Anthony Hopkins. Unfortunately for Graham, Hannibal has not forgotten that Graham was responsible for his changed circumstances.<br /><br />It is Hannibal Lecter, after all, who was the catalyst for Will Graham's retirement. The viewer is treated to scenes of Lecter's life, before he was revealed to be Hannibal the Cannibal, one of the sickest serial killers ever to strike. The viewer sees the renowned psychiatrist in his milieu as an erudite, cultured, and wealthy patron of the arts. A noted gourmand, Dr. Lecter liked nothing better than to give intimate dinner parties for the favored few. Of course, some of the ingredients used for his dinners were best left unsaid. It was nice to see the always excellent John Rubenstein in the small role of a dinner guest, heaping accolades upon Hannibal for his dinner parties.<br /><br />The movie is compelling and, at all times, gripping. Anthony Hopkins reprises his career defining role and steals the show (Really, Hannibal Lecter has become all but a cottage industry for him!). With a twinkle in his eye, he is, in his low key way, deliciously malevolent. Edward Norton, one of the best young actors around, gives a decent and sensitive portrayal of Will Graham, the angst ridden former FBI agent and profiler, but lacks the grittiness and hard-edged veneer that the role really demands. He also simply looks too young and soft for the role. Ralph Fiennes gives a fine performance as the tormented Francis Dolarhyde, but his portrayal is hampered by the fact that too little is revealed in the film about what makes him tick.<br /><br />Emily Watson affectingly plays a blind woman who becomes romantically involved with Francis Dolarhyde. It is her involvement with him that helps bring the film to its stunning conclusion. Moreover, Ms. Watson is a wonderfully talented British actress who manages to get her American accent down pat. Good performances by Harvey Keitel, as Graham's former boss, and Mary Louise Parker, as Graham's wife, round out this fine, ensemble cast.<br /><br />This film is a taut, unnerving psychological thriller that is subject to comparison to its 1986 predecessor \\"Manhunter\\". Having seen both, I call it a draw. This current version had a bigger budget, so obviously it has better production values. Also, the opening scenes in the current version are more interesting than those in the 1986 one. Music, however, was used to much better effect in the earlier version. Moreover, the final scenes in the earlier version were much better than in this later version, as they were much more suspenseful. Both films, however, are worth watching. Do yourself a favor and view both. Then, judge for yourself.soft for the role. It is her involvement with him that helps bring the film to its stunning conclusion. Moreover, Ms. Watson is a wonderfully talented British actress who manages to get her American accent down pat. Having seen both, I call it a draw. This current version had a bigger budget, so obviously it has better production values. Also, the opening scenes in the current version are more interesting than those in the 1986 one. Music, however, was used to much better effect in the earlier version. Moreover, the final scenes in the earlier version were much better than in this later version, as they were much more suspenseful. Both films, however, are worth watching. B0009WK5CW|5.0|This film is loosely based upon Robert Ludlum's book \\"The Bourne Identity\\". It is not a faithful adaptation nor is it intended to be. The book was just a springboard for something a little different. Having read the book and loved it, I also really enjoyed this movie. They are both excellent. Each forges its own path and entertains in its own way.<br /><br />The plot is simple, or so it seems. A man is found in the ocean with two bullets in his back. He is rescued by a trawler of Italian fishermen. When he regains total consciousness, he has no idea who he is or what he was doing that caused him to be floating in the ocean in the condition in which he had been. He shortly discovers his name to be Jason Bourne, and it appears that a great many people are trying to kill him, though for what purpose he has no idea.<br /><br />Jason Bourne (Matt Damon) also discovers that he has some unusual gifts and automatic, instinctive responses in certain situations. It turns out that he is a natural \\"Bourne\\" killer (pun intended). Jason teams up with a German expatriate named Maria (Franka Potente), and together they run into some heavy duty action, as they run for their lives. Meanwhile, a team of CIA trained assassins, dispatched by Bourne's boss, a CIA honcho named Conklin (Chris Cooper), are hot on the plucky couple's trail. There are a number of stunts and action scenes that are guaranteed to make one's palms start to sweat.<br /><br />Matt Damon, looking very buff, portrays Bourne as an intelligent, resourceful character with a core of goodness imbedded in his assassin's psyche. He is simply terrific. Franka Potente is good as the free spirited Maria, who is also resourceful and Jason's love interest in the film, though, quite frankly, very few sparks fly between them. Chris Cooper is excellent as Bourne's boss, Conklin. He is coldly efficient and brutal in his mop-up operation. Unlike Bourne, he lacks that core of goodness.<br /><br />This is an action packed, inventive, spy thriller that will hold the viewer in its thrall. This film revives that genre of film that was beginning to get a little stale. Kudos to Damon for giving the viewer something fresh and entertaining in this genre. 1577314808|5.0|The Power Of Now is an exceptional book brimming with the peace and wisdom that unfolds from the realization of one of the simplest yet most profound truths: Now is all there IS.  <br /> <br />There is a wonderful Zen Koan:  <br />Q: What in this moment is missing? <br />A: Nothing. <br /> <br />This is a fundamental and extraordinarily powerful truth that is directly and immediately verifiable to anyone. Simply, the universe IS. There can never be anything missing because the universe is ALL there is any moment. You live your life at the intersection of here and now. The past is gone forever, so let it go, and the future has yet to be, so let it come in it's own time. Thus, to accept what IS in any given moment is the most rational and intelligent of responses leading to a much happier, richer, and more satisfying existence.  <br /> <br />Yet, our ego mind is conditioned to avoid the present moment by constantly projecting itself into memories of the past or imagining a future that may never arrive. When that happens we lose touch with Reality, with what is so, and hypnotize ourself into living in attachment to an illusion that can only lead to suffering, as our illusions of how things should be, could be, or would be, will inevitably collide with the reality of how things actually are.  <br /> <br />Learning to accept what IS and just BE won't turn you into a blissed-out do-nothing. On the contrary, what you experience is that you can be happy now, without conditions, AND take action in the direction of your goals, rather than waiting for conditions to be different first before allowing yourself to be happy and enjoy your life. <br /> <br />This is so simple that many people find it extremely difficult to grasp, let alone accept. In fact, paradoxically, it takes considerable effort and much practice to decondition ourselves and just Be.  <br /> <br />As a professional life & career coach, I work daily with my clients to assist them in this awareness and understanding. This book has been extremely helpful in that process, for that is what Eckhart Tolle attempts to address: that who you are, not your ego or personality, but your true Being and genuine contentment is only experienced in the Now. <br /> <br />

B000IOM0YM|5.0|I just want to clear up the bonus disc issue for anyone looking to buy this set. If this information has already been posted (and for those already aware), please pardon the repetition.    It appears that the 3rd Bonus Disc (Limited Edition - 1977 Capital Centre - Largo, MD) is a promo item exclusive to certain retailers, namely Wal-Mart. I recently saw this set advertised on television, and Wal-Mart was the only retailer specified at the end of the ad as carrying the item, obviously as a plug for Wal-Mart. Additionally, while shopping this month, I noticed that Wal-Mart carries only the set with the Bonus Disc, while other stores carry only the 2-Disc set. Both items also have different UPC codes.    So, anyone looking for the Bonus Disc set needs to be careful about buying online, as there seems to have been some early confusion about where to get the bonus disc. Be sure to ask your used seller which version they are offering.    As for the Kissology set itself, I did receive the 3-Disc version as a gift, but have not yet watched it in its entirety. While being familiar with most of the content, my general impression of the set is that it is a quality product that is well worth the retail price for even the most marginal of Kiss fans. I say this due to the fact that this material is FINALLY available in a non-perishable format. Anyone who is familiar with the 1985 Live Aid DVD set, and what a laborious task it was for the producers of that set to assemble the few bits of quality footage that actually survived, should appreciate why this Kissology set is so valuable. It is a sad fact that master tapes degrade over time, and with the footage in this set being 30+ years old, it is a blessing that we have this much complete footage to enjoy in a format that will not degrade (at least not in our lifetime). I, for one, am happy for that, and it is for this reason alone that I feel it deserves 5 stars.

B00004XONN|5.0|Where to begin? I was glad to read the Amazon reviews beforehand to make sure I knew exactly what I was getting into once I heard this experimental album from Radiohead . . .  weird, adventurous, electronic music that touches your soul but takes time to appreciate. Got it. Everything In Its Right Place is a distortion of sounds (Thom's stuttering what I make out as `Kid A') that had me first scratching my head in confusion and finally enjoying it as a fantastic opener to the album. The National Anthem is a nice jazzy song with unbalanced trumpets that became my instant favorite. It makes you wanna dance. Optimistic is a beautiful, soaring, unconventionally uplifting piece of work and my favorite song on the album. \\"You can try the best you can, the best you can is good enough\\" has become my personal motto. Idioteque is an eerie track containing a sort of dance beat about what seems to me the end of the world or some nuclear war which is unavoidable. Typical Radiohead - their lyrics really shine. This album is a masterpiece but I can understand why people won't like it. It's a hard album to love. Simply put, I love it because it's bold. B000G8NXYG|5.0|Seven Samurai, simply put, is one of the greatest films ever made. I love movies. I love all genres, but I was NEVER a fan of foreign films. I was the typical American movie-goer. \\"You mean I gotta read subtitles? To hell with this.\\" was my attitude. That all changed with two American films, that ironically has a large portion of them subtitled.  <br />The flashback scenes to the young Vito Corleone in Godfather II were in Italian with subtitles. Two thirds of Dances with Wolves was subtitled. Those two films showed me that if the story is strong and the characters are engaging, I didn't mind subtitles.  <br />With that in mind I approached Kurosawa. The film makers I admired most, Lucas, Spielberg, Scorsese, all cited Kurosawa as a major influence and I was very curious. My prejudice against foreign film had always prevented me from exploring. Once I had that out of the way, I was able to explore. <br />Turner Classics ran Seven Samurai one night. I recorded it and watched it, the next morning. I was in awe. In my life there have been three films that completely floored me, three films that left me awestruck, Star Wars at age 8, Schindler's List, and I added Seven Samurai to that short list. <br />Strength of story, strength of character, strength of the filmmaker and his technique, there is not a single weak point in this film. When you factor in this was Kurosawa's first Samurai film, it make the accomplishment all the more stunning. <br />

And at The Mirage is a custom-built theater with surround sound, video projections and 360-degree seating to deliver a stunning stage and musical performance.<br /><br />The CD kicks into gear near the end, with Harrison's feedback guitar driving Revolution, which flawlessly transitions into Back In The USSR and seques to the best track, While My Guitar Gently Weeps, with Harrison's biting acoustic guitar and a new orchestral arrangement by Sir George Martin bringing a new, more powerful meaning to the lyrics.<br /><br />As a CD, there are more misses than hits when mixing songs into new packages. B0000AOV85|5.0|This is, without a doubt, the foremost in the \\"Classic Albums\\" series. A very well put together piece analyzing the leading-up-to and production of what is arguably the greatest rock album ever made. All four members of the Floyd give interviews, as well as their manager and sound engineers. Pretty much everyone who was directly involved with the production of this album gets airtime. One of the seminal feautures of the \\"Classic Albums\\" series, and very well done on this particular part of the series, is footage of the band members and/or sound engineer at the mixer giving a track deconstruction, isolating certain vocals or instruments, detailing effects laid on top of tracks--it's amazing stuff, so strange to hear things like \\"Us and Them\\" without the echoes overlaid onto David Gilmour's vocals. If you are a fan of \\"Dark Side\\" this is a must-own. A truly wonderful glimpse into the genius that created this remarkable album.

B000002UR7|5.0|It may surprise some people to discover that Radiohead wasn't always the experimental and disturbed rock band that they are today.  It may surprise those people even more to discover that Radiohead began as an early-90s alt-rock band like any other.  In 1993, they released their debut album, PABLO HONEY, and it was a debut like any other ... or so you'd be led to believe.  As a die-hard Radiohead fan, I knew that I must someday investigate PABLO HONEY, despite its lack of acknowledgement from many of my fellow fans.  Finally, I did, and was I ever surprised! <br /> <br />Maybe PABLO HONEY's lack of attention grew from comparisons to later Radiohead masterpieces like THE BENDS (which actually has a lot in common with PABLO HONEY) or their supreme achievement, OK COMPUTER.  It's fascinating to listen to PABLO HONEY and then listen to the band's most recent album, HAIL TO THE THIEF.  They sound like a completely different group.  It's no secret that Radiohead evolved and changed immensely over the course of six albums, but does that mean that they weren't a talented band to start out with?  Erase your prejudice and your expectations and listen to PABLO HONEY.  It's a collection of visceral ruminations on everything from mental status (\\"Vegetable\\") to love (\\"Thinking About You\\") to the apocalypse and how handy it would be to have a guitar during that time (\\"Anyone Can Play Guitar\\").  Each song features swirling, driven guitar and oddly angelic singing from Thom Yorke.  The lyrics are heartfelt and the arrangements show definite promise.  One way to describe Radiohead on PABLO HONEY would be \\"the U2 of the early-90s alt-rock scene.\\"  The overall sound of the album is very similar to that of THE BENDS, which is why I find it especially odd that this album has been disregarded by almost everyone. <br /> <br />Is PABLO HONEY as good as THE BENDS?  No.  Is it as good as OK COMPUTER?  No.  I suppose one might consider this Radiohead's weakest recording, although AMNESIAC holds that position in my book.  Try to examine this as what it is, though: an unpretentious debut from am immensely-talented band just starting out at the beginning of the 1990s.  It's not as good as the later Radiohead releases, but for what it is it's one of the most important albums of the decade, and certainly one of the best of the early 90s.
B000AJJNPY|4.0|This recent effort by Icelandic atmospheric/post-rock band Sigur Rós is a more polished, more studio-produced sounding, more mainstream and pop-infused album than some previous efforts.  This can make the songs more melodic and catchy, with hints of accordion/concertina, glockenspiel or toy piano, and electronic pad sounds.  This meanders in a slightly different direction than some of the more esoteric, abstract previous works.  These songs tend to fit into a \\"radio format\\" length and style.  Some people will absolutely love this new sound of Sigur Rós; diehard fans of the band's older sounds (more atmospheric, guitar-driven, and experimental) may be fairly put-off and disappointed, however. <br /> <br />If I were to describe the new sound, it sounds to me like some of the riffs and themes from fellow Icelandic band Múm combined with the driving, pulsing rhythms of Texan post-rockers Explosions in the Sky, with the recognizable old-school Sigur Ros vocals woven underneath.  Since I am a huge fan of Sigur Rós, Múm, and Explosions in the Sky, to me the new sound is fine and welcome -- in fact I prefer it over some of the more abstract previous works by Sigur Ros.  However, if you are looking for the long, sweeping progressive guitar-distorted-ambience sounds of Sigur Ros or if you are more into experimental music ala Radiohead's \\"Kid A\\", then I would say this album might not be for you.
B000JJRIN4|2.0|In 2004 Gwen Stefani took a leap and jumped out from being No Doubt's lead member to being a solo leader of her own, with her delicious debut 'Love.Angel.Music.Baby.'  The sound was fresh yet familiar and immediately struck a chord with many fans and critics alike, garnering several Grammy nominations including Album of the Year.  Sadly the standout singles; \\"What You Waiting For?\\", \\"Crash\\", and even \\"Cool\\" were blacked out by the major success of \\"Rich Girl\\", \\"Hollaback Girl\\" (Gwen's first #1 hit ever and the #2 song of the year), and even \\"Luxurious\\".   <br /> <br />Taking note of this, her second solo release 'The Sweet Escape' churned out even more mindless R&B and Rap like sound in hopes of duplicating the success of \\"Hollaback Girl\\".  I must admit, as many others shamefully do, that when I first heard \\"Hollaback Girl\\" I liked it, hell, I even... loved it.  Somehow, spelling out bananas and saying sh** thirty-eight times was entertaining.  I'm not criticizing the song, although many have, or any of the others with the same style from Gwen's debut.  They were alright but that was only three songs just 25% of the album. <br /> <br />'The Sweet Escape' on the other hand contains seven which is over half of the album, she strays away from pop which she does very well, and tries to conform for record sales and chart status.  The lead single, \\"Wind It Up\\" has already become a chart success (due mostly to downloads, the only thing that seems to matter at Billboard, instead of airplay as it used to and should be) peaking at #6.  Personally, I enjoy \\"Wind It Up\\" but like the one jewel in a pile of stones it's practically the only enjoyable 'upbeat' song. \\"Orange County Girl\\" sounds like something from the Orange County jail, an annoying slew of rap... from a white girl.  On \\"Now That You Got It\\", the title is repeated more times than sh** is repeated in \\"Hollaback Girl\\".   <br /> <br />Speaking of sh**, in \\"Don't Get It Twisted\\" the chorus goes a little like this, \\"Don't get it twisted, don't get clever, this is the most craziest sh** ever.\\" Need I say more? On \\"Breakin' Up\\" every line is repeated two or three times in a row, which gets annoying about 30 seconds into the song.  While \\"Yummy\\" is mildly entertaining the lyrics are questionable (\\"Diet drama\\" and \\"I know you've been waiting but I've been off making babies, and like a chef making donuts and pastries it's time to make you sweat\\").  The title track is alright, the chorus makes up for the lacking verses. <br /> <br />Now, like I've already stated, here's the pop gems that Gwen shines on.  \\"Early Winter\\" is a beautiful track expressing that her and her lying lover are having an 'early winter'.  Next is \\"4 in the Morning\\" begging her lover to give her everything because she's given all of her.  In the sexy \\"Fluorescent\\" she's amazed by how wonderful her lover is.  \\"U Started It\\" is similar, giving in to what her lover started claiming \\"we argue sometimes but not tonight\\".  The ending track is also one of the best, in \\"Wonderful Life\\" she reminisces of a past lover but reminds herself it's a 'wonderful life'. <br /> <br />In the end, while the innovative L.A.M.B. flew with flying colors and easily passes with an A (4 ½ stars).  'The Sweet Escape' needs to find some originality and leaves me with a rotten taste in my mouth, barely passing with a C (2 ½ stars).
B000EGDC0A|3.0|OK, so Alison goes mainstream. B000002TQV|5.0|In 1995, a slightly-popular alt-rock band called Radiohead released their second album, THE BENDS, and suddenly their bubble of isolation burst and they found themselves in the spotlight.  In the minds of many fans, it was on THE BENDS that Radiohead was truly born; many people choose to ignore the group's underrated debut PABLO HONEY.  THE BENDS is certainly a wonderful place for one to begin investigating the sensational work of Radiohead. <br /> <br />On THE BENDS, Radiohead decided to take it up a notch from PABLO HONEY - actually, more like thirty notches.  The band carried over their airy sound from PABLO HONEY, but left behind their visceral attitude, replacing it with an atmosphere of dreamy confusion and bewilderment.  Sure, there's pounding drums and driving guitars, but Thom Yorke's voice makes it perfectly clear that the band feels as lost as they do frustrated.  Each of the album's 12 compositions are absolutely stellar, and it's hard to pick favorites.  One of the most popular songs from the album is \\"Fake Plastic Trees\\", a sorrowful serenade played repeatedly in the teen comedy classic CLUELESS.  The lyrics are poignantly meaningful and brilliantly concealing, and the music itself is nothing short of excellent.  True, the production does sound a little rough, but that's part of the album's charm - something it has a lot of. <br /> <br />THE BENDS is considered by some Radiohead fans to be the band's finest record, and that's not hard to imagine - it's neither as pessimistic as OK COMPUTER nor as off-puttingly experimental as KID A, though it's clear on \\"Planet Telex\\" especially that the band was already beginning to experiment.  THE BENDS was an overwhelming critical success, hailed by many as the best album of 1995 and even by some as one of the best albums ever recorded (it was ranked 110th on Rolling Stone's list of The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time).  It's lost none of its impressiveness or popularity since its release, and continues to astoundlegions of curious listeners.  If you're looking to investigate Radiohead, start here.
B000GY729M|2.0|Many of the other reviews already succinctly summed up the strengths and weakness of this album:    + The album strives to differentiate itself from Hot Fuss by focusing on hometown-based lyrics and less Britpop-infused sounds.    - Having said that, most of the album is rather droll and repetitive.  It is not so much BAD as it is simply mediocre: noisy, fuzzy, flat and forgettable.  If the original Killers sounded like a tribute to gritty turn-of-the-80's Iggy Pop and the Cure, the new Killers sound more like a tribute band to the Killers -- almost like they are doing a cheap cover-band imitation of themselves.  Aside from the popular radio single \\"When You Were Young\\", the rest of the album is nearly devoid of the catchy hooks and mind-penetrating off-kilter melodies that abounded in Hot Fuss.    It looks like the sophomore curse has reached yet another band.  I do have faith (and hope) that they might be able to find themselves again and branch into a wonderful new sound with a 3rd album, but for now I would recommend waiting it out and avoiding purchase of this one.

0440418569|5.0|It's for kids, but will be appreciated by adults that like fantasy/star trek like stories as well.
0618680004|4.0|This is a much needed book that should have been written earlier. Although I welcome it as a step in the right direction I have several reservations about it. While Dawkins hopes that after reading this book a believer will become an atheist I just don't think he is tough enough on religion. For one thing, he is not using all the ammunition at his disposal. Not even the full implications of evolution and modern cosmology are analyzed. For another thing, he digresses into irrelevant subjects. Divinely ordered biblical genocide, Crusades and the Spanish Inquisition are entirely missing, but we do get paeans to the literal and cultural influence of the King James Bible. When I asked him about the omission of the Inquisition and the Crusades at a lecture he gave in New York he brushed it aside as something that \\"everybody knows.\\" Well, everybody does not know as a general murmor from the audience revealed, and these were not uneducated people but members of the New York Academy of Sciences. And missing also are non-Abrahamic religions, for reasons of \\"unfamiliarity.\\" This is a weak excuse for not having done your homework. Not just the track record of Abrahamic religions but the track record of religion in its entirety must be made clear. This is very important because people are not disturbed by what they do not know, and without a knowledge of such \\"strange\\" religions as those of Mesoamerica we simply do not comprehend the true evils that religion is capable of. But first let us look at what the book actually gives us. He very ably covers the ground that needs to be covered within his stated limitation to Abrahamic religions, shows the emptiness of proofs for God's existence and goes even beyond that by discussing some more primitive religions. Historically, Bertand Russell covered most of it in his 1927 essay \\"Why I Am Not a Christian.\\"(1) And more recently, Sam Harris has written a hard-hitting book \\"The End of Faith\\" (2) which Dawkins likes. That book drew thousands of letters from Christians with a hugely negative response which motivated him to respond by publishing another book called \\"A Letter to a Christian Nation.\\"(3) He laments in it that \\"This letter is a product of failure - the failure of the many brilliant attacks upon religion that preceded it - failures great and small that have kept almost every society on this earth muddling over God and despising those that muddle differently.\\" And he is right - true believers generally find a way to weasel-word themselves out of criticism that should settle the matter. It is not surprising then that the present book has also come under fire. Jim Holt headlines his critique of it in The New York Times Book Review as \\"Beyond Belief\\"(4). To him, reading the book is a little like watching a Michael Moore movie. He finds the least satisfying part of the book Dawkins's treatment of the traditional arguments for the existence of God - the ontological, cosmological and design arguments - which Dawkins rightly dismisses as vacuous  because they rely upon the idea of regress and invoke God to terminate it (5). And Darwinian evolution's ability to construct complex organisms is juxtaposed with the same old argument about entropy increase that a multitude of creationists have been using. And then he wants Dawkins to also tell him why there is a universe at all, a question that seems to bother theologians a lot! H. Allen Orr (6) who should know better also attacks him in the pages of The New York Review of Books. He is a geneticist but simply lacks a coherent view of nature. To him Dawkins is \\"...a kind of latter-day T. H. Huxley.\\" And then he attacks science itself: \\"Why... is Dawkins so untroubled by his own (large) assumption that both matter and the laws of nature can be viewed as given?\\" he asks.  That takes us back to the twelfth century Muslim philosopher Abu Hamid al-Ghazzali who objected to laws of nature simply because they would \\"...put God's hands in chains.\\" He was of course right. The result of unhanding God: no more Muslim science that amounted to anything. The rest of Orr is worse and descends to a name-calling orgy. Arguments about God can now be found even in a magazine like National Geographic. In the February 2007 issue John Horgan (7) interviews Francis Collins whose recent book \\"The Language of God\\"(8) embraces God and dismisses the conflict between science and religion by assuming that what is in the scripture should not be taken literally but figuratively. He is really good at sidestepping issues. When asked about religious terrorism he quips: \\"...we shouldn't judge the pure truths of faith by the way they are applied... We shouldn't blame faith for the ways people distort it and misuse it.\\" Five hundred years of inquisition - one third of the time that Chistianity was the dominant faith of Europe - was just a distortion then that does not count against God. On the problem of evil, he excuses God this way: \\"God gave us free will, and we may choose to exercise it in ways that end up by hurting other people.\\" Never mind the all-good, omniscient, omnipotent God of the theologians. At least one of these attributes has to be missing: he is either not omnipotent or he is not all-good. I vote for a malevolent God who is omnipotent and wishes us ill. Steven Weinberg (a physicist) once asked why six million jews, including his relatives, had to die in the Holocaust so that the Nazis could exercise their free will. Collins's take on this: \\"If God had to intervene miraculously every time one of us chose to do some evil, it would be a very strange, chaotic, unpredictable world.\\" Really. If the millions butchered in genocides did not move him to act why expect him to act on prayers of ordinary people? He is clearly a malevolent God who wanted this to happen. Consider his track record: twice he was involved in human sacrifice, once with Abraham where he relented. He instigated Joshua to murder everyone in Jericho and he himself oncedrowned the entire human race except for one family he kept as breeding stock.    But he is not the only malevolent God we know of: in the Old World Baal, his rival, very likely demanded human sacrifices as well since that is what Baal-Hammon worship at Carthage involved. So did another Caananite deity, Moloch. And the New World gods that we know of were almost all malevolent, dreaded deities that demanded human sacrifice on a grand scale. Here is how Marvin Harris (9) describes the temple precinct of Tenochtitlan, the Aztec capital:    Nowhere else in the world had there developed a state-sponsored religion whose art, architecture, and ritual were so thoroughly dominated by violence, decay, death, and disease. Nowhere else were walls and plazas of great temples and palaces reserved for such a concentrated display of jaws, fangs, talons, bones, and gaping death heads. The eyewitness accounts of Cortez and his fellow conquistador, Bernal Diaz, leave no doubt concerning the ecclesiastical meaning of the dreadful visages portrayed in stone. The Aztec gods ate people. They ate human hearts and they drank human blood. And the declared function of the Aztec priesthood was to provide fresh human hearts and human blood in order to prevent the remorseless deities from becoming angry and crippling, sickening, withering and burning the whole world.    As we shall see, the depths of human depravation under the theocratic empire of the Aztecs give a whole new meaning to the words \\"established religion.\\"     Another weak point of Dawkins is his lack of emphasis on the pernicious influence of belief in a soul that survives death. By excluding major non-Abrahamic religions, any discussion of the Hindu doctrine of \\"suttee\\" which derives directly from that belief is also eliminated. Suttee (or sati) means \\"dutiful wife.\\" The duty consists of a widow throwing herself into the flames of her dead husband's funeral pyre so that her soul can commune with his. Should she hesitate, her husband's relatives will give her a helping hand. It was made illegal by the British in 1831 but survived into the twentieth century in backwoods India. There are ultraorthodox Hindus who would like to reinstate it. This is just one example of the inhuman consequences that belief in the soul has caused. It is a very ancient belief. Thousands of years before the Bible was even written, the royal graves of the Old Kingdom pharaohs in Egypt were surrounded by \\"subsidiary\\" graves (10) of servants, sacrificed so that their souls could continue to serve their master in the next world. Likewise, the royal graves of Sumerian kings at Ur of the Chaldees contained the bodies of up to eighty five servants, also sacrificed so that their souls could provide a ghostly retinue for the departed king. And in Russia too, the Scythians who inhabited the steppes in the first millennium B.C. built royal graves called \\"kurgans\\" where the body of the king was accompanied by his queen and household members, all sacrificed to start his new household in the next world. But the Shan dynasty Chinese outdid them all. With their king they buried his concubines, his household members and his guards, enough to start a new royal court in the next world. Over a two hundred year period near the end of the second millennium B.C. they extracted the souls from thirty five thousand people for this worthy purpose.     I wish it were ancient history but it isn't. Muslim extremists are now utilizing belief in the soul to recruit suicide bombers. If you kill yourself for Allah, they are told, you are a martyr, your soul goes straight to paradise, you are rewarded there with seventy two virgins for your sexual pleasure, and thirty two of your relatives will get to heaven when they die without having to submit to final judgement. (11) Thousands of volunteers have signed up, the 9/11 hijackers among them. Even worse, we now see a spectacle of mothers praising their children's martyrdom, presumably because it gets themselves also into paradise regardless of their sins. And in the West we are not free of this superstition either: the concept of the soul still bedevils us in the guise of the \\"right to life\\" movement. For right-to-lifers, life starts at conception not because the genes from both parents are present but because the miracle of \\"ensoulment\\" has taken place: a soul has entered the fertilized egg. They know how weird this sounds so they don't talk about it much. But to them, that zygote with a soul and the embryo it grows into are complete human beings with \\"rights.\\" Which makes abortion as well as use of the early embryo as a source of stem cells murder and explains their irrational stand against stem cell research. And the soul dispossessed by stem cell research goes straight to hell through no fault of its own because it is filled with Adam's \\"original sin\\" which only baptism can remove. In case you wonder what part of the Bible this comes from, it doesn't. Moses was entirely ignorant of the existence of a soul, Ecclesiastes did not know about it either, and Paul insisted that it is not a soul at all but a dead human body, raised from the grave on Resurrection Day and made \\"incorruptible,\\" that goes to heaven.      Human sacrifice of children was also apparently a practice in biblical times, judging by the story of Abraham who agreed to sacrifice his son to God. Baal, god of the Phoenicians and a bane to the priests of Yahweh, was also god of the Carthaginians who called it Baal-Hammon. He demanded burnt offerings of Carthaginian children who had to be brought to the temple by the mother (12). \\"Mother and child\\" statuettes, found in Carthaginian settlements in Corsica, testify to this custom. The child was roasted in a temple oven or on an outdoor burning ground known as a tophet. In Carthage, a children's cemetery (13) still survives. Thousands of victims as well as a few dogs are buried there, suggesting that under some conditions it was permissible to substitutea dog for a child. In the New World, human sacrifice was nearly universal. Best known is the Aztec custom of sacrificing and then eating war prisoners. The emperor was also the high priest who presided at the more important ceremonies.  On top of a pyramid now called \\"Templo Mayor\\" in Mexico City were two temples, one dedicated to the rain god Tlaloc and another one to their chief god Huichilopochtly. When Cortez, the conquistador, was still emperor Montezuma's guest he was taken up the 114 steps of the great pyramid and was shown three hearts being burned and numerous other hearts of victims they had sacrificed that day. (14) The smell, his companions reported, was worse than that in a Spanish slaughterhouse. The victims of Tlaloc were children and they had to be made to cry because it was out of their tears that he created rain. Huichilopochtly's victims were mostly war prisoners as befits a war god. Victims  were fattened for sacrifice since they were to become food of the gods (15). Four priests held the victim spread-eagled on the altar while a fifth one opened the chest with an obsidian knife and took out the still-beating heart (16). Arms and legs belonged to the soldier who captured him and were used in a sacred meal for which recipes have survived. The trunk was thrown to the jaguars and heads of victims were posted on a head rack called a tzompantli in temple square. This was not a small operation, for their empire stretched from the Atlantic to the Pacific. In addition to supplying prisoners for sacrifice at the capital local towns had their own gods that were just as bloodthirsty (17).  In 1521, when Cortez with his conquistadors and indian allies finally took over Tenochtitlan, they found more than two hundred thousand human heads on display in the temple district. These were not only on tzompantlis but also cemented together into a towerlike structure. Aztec sources related that at the dedication of the great pyramid in 1487 four lines of prisoners stretching for two miles each were sacrificed by a team of executioners who worked day and night for four days (18). An estimated 14,100 prisoners lost their lives in that single event which remains the only competitor to the efficiency of the Nazi killing machine at Auschwitz. According to one version of Aztec theology their god Huichilopochtly was a creator god in charge of the present or fifth world, four previous ones having been created and destroyed by a medley of other gods. His rule for the Aztecs of this world: bring me human blood every day or I will destroy your world too. The Aztecs obliged by sacrificing war prisoners to him. But to get war prisoners you need a war. Another city, Tlaxcala, had a similar God problem and periodically they went to war against each other. These wars were called \\"flower wars\\" and when both sides had taken enough prisoners peace was declared and everyone went back to worshiping their gods again. Possibly one in four Mesoamerican males ended up as food of the gods this way. It is true that New World human sacrifice does enter the book but only peripherally, through a news item about a young girl sacrificed by the Incas. He rightly criticises multiculturalist attempts to justify such atrocities as integral to native culture but then just drops the entire subject and thereby misses the true impact of what human sacrifice really meant in the Americas.     As to religion in general, no matter which one you look at it demands accepting a delusionary lifestyle. Religion is a product of human social evolution, made possible by possession of language, and is still evolving. It resists rational discourse because childhood indoctrination is effectively permanent. In biology, such behavior is called imprinting and there is a fair chance that something like imprinting has imprisoned the minds of the religious from childhood on. The Jesuits were right when they said \\"Give me a child until seven and I will give you the man.\\" In people like Collins that indoctrination was temporarily suppressed by education until it surfaced again when a suitable rationalization appeared. That rationalization to him was belief that God has miraculously put a \\"moral law\\" into our heads, something that C. S. Lewis (19) dreamed up in his book called \\"Mere Christianity.\\" But this is contradicted by the meticulous observations of Marc Hauser (20) in \\"Moral Minds.\\"  He carefully observes the development of moral behavior in children from infancy to adolescence and postulates the existence of a moral instinct similar to the language instict we all have. While imprinting by childhood indoctrination explains the persistence of religion it does not explain its origin. Possession of language is the sine qua non of religion which puts the probable date for its inception at least sixty thousand years into the past. Since practically all religions have some form of afterlife we also need a reason for introducing it from the start. With this in mind, it is likely that the initial stimulus was the very strong and long-lasting human emotion of grief that we share with other mammals. Suppose, for example, that Ugh, a stone age hunter, has been stepped on by a mastodon and is dead but his grieving wife has a dream in which he is still alive. She speaks about it to the local herbalist who says something like this: \\"Oh yes, he is alive in that happy hunting ground - and I know the head man there if you want to contact him.\\" Wishful thinking will make her want to believe this and not much more is needed to start a primitive religion. Word of mouth then garbles the details and all sorts of miraculous things become attributed to the head man, family and tribe of that happy hunting ground. \\"Psychics\\" today play the same game. Although it is possible that originally there was only one religion this is so easy that it could have happened multiple times in different groups. But belief in miracles that goes back to primitive religions is still withus. Collins in the National Geographic interview maintains they are real but then cops out by claiming that they are so rare that he personally does not expect to see one. By this device his view becomes empirically congruent with expectations of those of us for whom the world is controlled only by laws of nature.     And this view, if you like, is what constitutes the scientific world view. The most basic of these laws is quantum mechanics and its relativistic extension to nuclear matter known as the \\"Standard Model.\\" Thanks to its validity throughout the observable universe we know the conditions in distant galaxies since they are coded into the quantum properties of light reaching us. Quantum mechanics also controls the interactions between atoms from which the laws of chemistry derive. Linus Pauling in fact got his first Nobel prize working out the details of this in the thirties. And these laws of chemistry in turn control all chemical reactions in the universe, including all biochemical reactions that take place within living matter. Hence all life activities that are manifest to us are enabled by this underlying quantum layer of reality, leaving no room for anything like souls. Ruled out also are ghosts, spirits, gods, angels and devils, all guilty of violating the rules of quantum mechanics. There has never been an instance where quantum mechanical predictions of any kind have not been followed to the utmost precision by nature. The Bayesian probability of such sustained and correlated precision over the volume of cosmic space and time is so astronomical as to be incalculable. A true believer can still say \\"God made it so and he can change it if he wants to.\\" But more intelligent religionists like Collins know that the game is up and have decided to put God into hiding, somewhere outside of nature and outside of space and time (21). From that safe haven, they think, he can still make incursions into our universe. If so, there is absolutely no evidence that he has ever done so or ever will. Quantum mechanics is the antivirus that has been blocking any attempt of his to manipulate even an electron that belongs to this universe of ours. 6302886228|5.0|I saw this concert on VHS in the 90's.  I was lucky to find it at my video store.  Now, of course, it is practically unavailable on VHS, and not at all on DVD.  Why?  It is one of the  finest tribute concerts ever.  Each performance seems to rival the next for quality, and it goes on for at least a couple of hours.  For me, two of the highlights are Johnny Winter's revelatory version of Highway 61 Revisited and Vedder's Masters of War.  Who's here?  Oh, no one, just The Band, George Harrison, Eddie Vedder, Lou Reed, Neil Young, Roger Mcguinn and anyone the producers asked. Now, a lineup like that can lead either to epiphany or a terrible mistake.  Luckily, the former was the result.  One day it will go to DVD (how much longer they can ignore it may depend on the sagacity of whoever is minding Dylan's business end). and then everyone may get to experience this unforgettable night.

B0007Y89ZM|4.0|This is a very good concert DVD by an excellent band but the problem was that they left off so many classic Eagle songs.  Why didn't they perform \\"Heartache Tonight,\\" \\"The Long Run,\\" \\"Peaceful Easy Feeling,\\" \\"One Of These Nights,\\" \\"Lyin' Eyes,\\" \\"New Kid In Town,\\" etc.?  Also, even though Henley is my favorite member of the band, he sings too many songs here and Frey only got to sing three.  The first 2/3 of this DVD also only feature softer songs and the rock songs don't come until the end.  Plus, I think there is more chemistry and band interaction on the Farewell 1 DVD than there is on Hell Freezes over.  Now, with all that aside, I'll talk about what does work.  \\"Hotel California\\" is great in its alternate acoustic version even though I prefer the electric version but at least this one has Felder on guitar.  \\"Wasted Time\\" is probably better here (but still great on Farewell 1) since you have Henley behind the drums, Felder on guitar, and more shots of Walsh on organ.  \\"In The City\\" is great here but its just as good on Farewell 1.  \\"Get Over It\\" is an excellent song and performed very well featuring great guitar work from Walsh, Felder, and Frey although Henley I feel should have been behind the drums on that one.  \\"Tequila Sunrise\\" is great here but just as good on Farewell One.  \\"I Can't Tell You Why\\" is a stand out here particularly for Felder's guitar solos.  \\"Love Will Keep Us Alive\\" makes its debut here even if it's just as good on Farewell One.  \\"Desperado\\" is much better on Hell Freezes Over\\" than on Farewell 1 because you have the Eagles PLAYING the song rather than the backing musicians.  Some Henley solo stuff like \\"New York Minute\\" seem to drag a little, but \\"The Heart Of The Matter\\" does work well.  \\"The Last Resort\\" is a bit long but it is still performed very well.  Another real bonus is the interview and rehearsal footage.  So, this is a very good DVD but it could have been much better if more classic Eagle songs were included but what does work here works very well.

0385720920|4.0|The votes are pretty much in on Palahniuk, but allow me a few lines, since this is the first book of his I've read. I was turned on to him by the girl who does my hair, who said people fainted and vomited at his readings. With that endorsement in mind, I picked up Choke, CP's first best-seller. The story is one of a sex addict and his troubled relationship with his crazy mother, who is dying in a hospital. That's about it for plot, though we do follow our anti-hero to sex addiction meetings, his colonial Williamsburg-esque job site, and on visits to the strip clubs. This book is not so much about content as it is about style. And stylistically, it is a fast paced narrative filled with unrelenting cynicism. In the care of worse writers than CP, this could get tiresome and grim. But Choke is a laugh-out-loud funny book. The early chapter on the sex addiction meetings is hilarious. What is better than sex?, our narrator asks us. It's perhaps the best chapter in the book. The novel is really a lamentation. Victor could be called Jeremiah for all the teeth gnashing he does. The novel reminded a lot of Kurt Vonnegut. The \\"it's the first word that comes to mind\\" line that is repeated throughout reminded me of the \\"so it goes\\" line from Slaughterhouse Five. My main problems was with the ending, which is convoluted, rushed, and altogether unsatisfying. The later chapter on trysts in airplanes could've been left on the cutting room floor. But on the whole, this is a good book. I'm not sure if I'll read more CP soon. But I'm glad I read Choke.

B00092ZMDY|5.0|I waited a long time to purchase this DVD.  It wasn't because of the set list because the band chose basically all the classic Eagles songs plus some solo hits from Walsh, Henley, and one from Frey along with three new songs.  It wasn't because I wasn't an Eagles fan because they are one of my favorite bands.  It was because Don Felder was absent.  But then I started to read reviews of the DVD which were mostly very positive and I rationalized that I did own the Who DVD (post Moon) Royal Albert Hall and I still think it's outstanding so I figured why not give the Eagles Farewell 1 tour a shot.  I'm very glad that I did because it has become one of my favorite concert DVDs.  The sound on this DVD is amazing and the camera work is fantastic.  Also, like the other reviewers said, the Eagles perform their songs as they should be heard and they perform almost all their classic songs and then some.  Okay, Felder is absent from the concert, but Henley, Frey, Walsh, and Schmitt help you forget about him plus Stuart Smith plays Felder's parts just as Felder would have played them.  Plus, Felder never sang lead vocals that much with the Eagles and the Eagles are a band that concentrates on vocals as much as instruments.  Speaking of the band, they all sound great.  Henley has gained some weight but his singing is still top notch, his drumming and percussion skills are both excellent, and he even plays some acoustic and electric guitar.  He is an underated musician but his drumming was always a vital part of the Eagles sound just like his singing.  Frey thankfully sings a lot more here than he did on Hell Freezes Over (only 3 songs on that one).  Some reviewers said his voice was going a little but I totally disagree.  His voice (probably best voice in the band) still is outstanding and he does a fantastic job on guitar and keyboards.  Frey is also underated as a musician but his guitar and keyboard playing were also vital to the Eagles sound.  Frey is also the one who talks to the audience the most during the concert.  Walsh is definitely a true rock and roll star.  Both his guitar playing and singing during this concert are extraordinary.  He is definitely one of the best American guitar players ever.  Some Eagles fans did not think Walsh fit in with the band but I have to disagree.  Songs like \\"Hotel California,\\" \\"The Long Run,\\" \\"Life In The Fast Lane,\\" and \\"Heartache Tonight\\" would not have sounded as good without Walsh.  Schmitt is a little bit overshadowed by the other three in terms of singing but he still does a fantastic job on his two signatures songs (\\"I Can't Tell You Why\\" and \\"Love Will Keep Us Alive\\") and on bass and high harmonies.  Oddly enough, Schmitt is the only one who plays his instrument on every song throughout the DVD (there is at least one song where the other 3 only sing without playing anything).  The extra musicians do not hurt the performance at all and the horn section works here unlike with some other bands such as on The Who's Encore Disc of Tommy and Quadrophenia live.  The spotlight is still on Henley, Frey, Walsh, and Schmitt.  Highlights of this concert include \\"Heartache Tonight,\\" \\"Hotel California,\\" \\"Life In The Fast Lane,\\" \\"Already Gone,\\" \\"Peaceful Easy Feeling,\\" \\"Lyin' Eyes,\\" \\"Dirty Laundry,\\" \\"Take It Easy,\\" \\"In The City,\\" \\"Walk Away,\\" \\"You Belong To The City,\\" \\"Funk 49,\\" \\"The Boys Of Summer,\\" \\"New Kid In Town,\\" \\"One Of These Nights,\\" \\"I Can't Tell You Why,\\" \\"Tequila Sunrise,\\" \\"Wasted Time,\\" \\"The Long Run,\\" \\"Rocky Mountain Way,\\" \\"One Day At A Time,\\" \\"Life's Been Good,\\" and \\"Hole In The World.\\"  The only performance that doesn't do it for me is \\"Desperado.\\"  Don't get me wrong because I really like that song, but none of the Eagles really PLAY on it this time.  Frey doesn't play piano like he should and Henley should be behind the drums.  The performance for Hell Freezes Over is better.  That's the only let down, but Henley still sings the song very well.  For those who appreciate good humor, watchFrey and Walsh during \\"All She Wants To Do Is Dance.\\"  Anyway, if you are an Eagles fan and appreciate good music I would definitely recommend this DVD.  It's one of the best filmed concerts ever produced.

B00005JKGO|4.0|Long considered a major filmmaker, Federico Fellini established his reputation through an insistence on the interest-value of his own fantastic and idiosyncratic vision of the world... In so doing, however, he repeatedly lays himself open to charges of egomania, self-indulgence and superficiality; certainly much of his work, if visually extraordinary, is hyperbolic, naïve and incoherent...<br /><br />This film about the hedonistic, amoral life of Rome's \\"beautiful people\\" is really a series of startling episodes held together by a character played by Marcello Mastroianni, a gossip columnist who is himself caught up in the aimless, scandalous \\"sweet life.\\"<br /><br />Filled, like all Fellini films, with stunning, bizarre images and faces and marked by the director's wild comic imagination, the film was widely condemned as \\"vulgar, witless, and intellectually bankrupt\\" and lavishly praised as \\"a cultural and social document, as well as an exciting entertainment.\\"<br /><br />\\"La Dolce Vita\\" moves from one shocking sequence to another... It is a sprawling epic satire on what Fellini considered the spiritual malaise of modern society... It followed a journalist employed by a scandal magazine around a Rome obsessed with orgiastic parties, voluptuous film stars and the commercial marketing of religion... While its images are flamboyant--a statue of Christ flying above Rome suspended from a helicopter, Anita Ekberg dancing in the Trevi fountain, a kitten on her head--the film's despairing tone often rings meaningless, even though Mastroanni's compulsive womanizer, never glamorized, fails to achieve redemption...

Very soon after their arrival, each is accused of having brought about the death of another person and for that they are to pay. Agatha Christie seems to have covered all of her bases on this one to leave the reader attempting to figure out the clues. And exactly who can the killer be? <br /> <br />A well thought out mystery, very well done! <br />

B0001WTWCO|5.0|'The English Patient' is a love story set in Europe as World War II ends... It is a wartime romance mystery epic, like 'Hiroshima, Mon Amour,' 'The Sweet Hereafter,' and 'After Life.' Anthony Minghella weaves extravagant beauty around a central character whose condition is grotesque, and puts emotional barriers between the characters and the audience...<br /><br />This adult love story is an intimate portrait in the tradition of 'Casablanca' and 'Dr. Zhivago.' The film sweeps gracefully attaining a level of eroticism and emotional connection that many similar films had missed... Told in flashback, it is a masterpiece of intimate moment and spectacular largesse...<br /><br />Ralph Fiennes plays the English patient, Count Laszlo de Almasy, a Hungarian cartographer of few words, who works for the British government, and is stationed in the North African desert...<br /><br />Count Laszlo is the unidentified survivor of a plane crash turned over to the Allies, taken into custody by a medical convoy in Italy, and essentially left to die in peace, in an isolated monastery in Tuscany, under the care of an inspiring pretty nurse who injects him with morphine, and reads to him a book, considered his great treasure, and his one surviving possession...<br /><br />Hana seeks to stimulate his touching memories, wrapped up in his head, released in lost pieces from his disturbed mind...<br /><br />Fiennes gives a haunted, pained performance, playing the young man whose veneer of charm cannot plainly cover his heart's capacity for passion... He makes us sympathize with the character in showing self-doubt and weakness... As a badly burned man, he has only cherished memories... His joy and heartbreak are completely clear and visible in his eyes... He remembers falling under the spell of an attractive English married woman... He remembers the way this turns him from a harsh abrupt wanderer into a man willing to betray everything for love... His tragic love affair forms the heart of the motion picture...<br /><br />Kristin Scott Thomas matches Fiennes' work with a radiant sensuality... She is captivating as the married European woman, conveying the audience with the energy and enthusiasm for life that the Count finds irresistible... Their different world, despairing and hopeful, menacing and resilient, is simply beautiful... With intense passion and intelligence, this attractive blonde burns the screen as the different wife...<br /><br />Juliette Binoche seems to shine as the French-Canadian nurse full of life and energy... This vibrant young woman has a heart of gold, kissing wounded soldiers, but she thinks that she is a curse as anybody she ever loved tends to die on her...<br /><br />Colin Firth is good as Katherine's husband... He is a British spy flying into the tough desert in a yellow biplane to take aerial maps of the whole North African continent... He quickly becomes friend of the Count, yet when he realizes that his wife has committed adultery, his face reflected a peaceful fury...<br /><br />William Dafoe plays a double-agent spy who covers his anger with a strange charm... He is a crippled war veteran who has a hidden agenda... This cunning Canadian man seems to know of some dark secret in Almasy's past... He believes the 'English patient' is partially responsible for the mutilation of his hands, and is busy seeking revenge on everyone even remotely involved...<br /><br />Naveen Andrews is Hana's ardent lover... He is a handsome Sikh, and an explosives expert with a dangerous job... There's a scene that is stuck in my head because it literally had me on the edge of my seat for what seemed an eternity... The scene cuts back and forth between his tense face, the wires and his dirty fingers as they try madly to figure out how to untangle and cut the wires without detonating the bomb...<br /><br />All the conventional elements of the genre are at peaks of excellence in \\"The English Patient.\\" John Seale's cinematography is breathtaking, and Gabriel Yared's majestic music is dreamy, and romantic... This is a rich motion picture with ambition and style, a fever dream, lyrical and complex... We are almost able to feel the heat of the desert, the pain of the burnings, the intimate flush of humanity that becomes the most haunting element of this epic love story...es without detonating the bomb...  <br /> <br />All the conventional elements of the genre are at peaks of excellence in \\"The English Patient.\\" John Seale's cinematography is breathtaking, and Gabriel Yared's majestic music is dreamy, and romantic... B00005JPE7|3.0|With the first Rocky film, we are introduced to a decidedly American character.  A true blue collar hero who inspires the quiet majority is certainly a great accomplishment.  Sylvester Stallone merely looks outside at the real world and reflects in his film the squalor and the near-squalor surrounding and pressuring his main character.  We watch as he struggles to be the right man for a woman.  He struggles with his dreams and feelings of inadequacy, and through it all, we connect with him emotionally and we subsequently celebrate his victories.    The second film is essentially a director's extension to the first film, and it continues and concludes much more storyline than Stallone probably intended.  Stallone is so complete with the first Rocky movies that the third, fourth, and fifth movies have nowhere believable to begin, and it's painful to watch Stallone brutalize a character that he worked so hard to build.    Rocky Balboa is interesting to me because it shows how poor and unnecessary the third, fourth, and fifth Rocky films really are.  There's no need for Rocky to overcome the overly racial-ized Clubber Lang in Rocky III, or the Cold War Russian in Rocky IV.  By far the worst of the series, Rocky V nearly obliterates everything human about Rocky Balboa, turning him into a selfish jerk; he's always self-centered, but only in Rocky V does he make that unsympathetic turn into selfishness.    But with this final chapter, Stallone has attempted to own the mistakes of his Rocky series as well as finally write a conclusion worthy of the character he created 30 years ago.  Yes, the older Rocky lectures to us in clichés and he tells us \\"something [we] already know,\\" but he does it in a manner that is believable and insightful within the context of the character.  Stallone has rendered a good sense of desperation and pain for his older Rocky.  It's likely Stallone himself is going through these very same feelings as he ages and looks back at some mistakes and missteps in his career as well as the moments of greatness.    My uncle is 50 years old and in fantastic shape.  After seeing the film with his kids, he thought the film didn't have enough action and that it was more about thinking and feeling than the Rocky he knows.  His description of the film is accurate, but I'm not sure what else one can expect from Stallone.  Stallone is 60 years old and in great, great shape for his age.  He gives as good a physical display as possible in this final film, and he does not appear broken or apologetic because of his age.  There are few movies out there that actually respect the aging and the elderly.  Stallone has found a way.    It's also great to see Rocky continue to learn and not settle on old prejudices.  This struggle may be even more difficult than the physical challenges of the film.  Stallone displays a matured tenderness in a Platonic relationship with a younger woman that I wasn't expecting, and I appreciated the gesture.  Stallone seems to have touched on nearly everything in the Rocky world, tying up loose ends, finishing things.  Rocky Balboa could easily have been the conclusion to a trilogy instead of a disclaimer about what Stallone meant to say.    In the end, the film works for me.  Despite being sentimental, I actually believed Stallone's older Rocky, mostly because it's clear that Stallone believes what he's saying and doing in this film.  Better late than never.
B000ASSDVA|4.0|The ballad of the Cid, the story of Rodrigo Diaz de Bivar, who on his white stallion Babieca drove away the Moors from Spain and took to wife the proud Chimene who had sworn to kill him but lived to love him and became the mother of his daughters, has, like so many ballad of chivalry and heroism, come down to us from medieval times...<br /><br />It was left to Anthony Mann, director of the best Westerns of the 'fifties, to make the purest example of the the epic: the famous \\"El Cid.\\"<br /><br />With that stern, intense face and athletic figure, Charlton Heston was ideally cast... His performance was inspirational, pure and profoundly beautiful... He was indeed 'the only man in Spain who could humble a king and would give a leper a drink.'<br /><br />The grandeur of the film lead to a deeply moving climax: Inside the walled city of Valencia, the dying Cid, aware that his men might fall into confusion with the next attack of the Moors without him in command, and knowing that he cannot last the night, obtained the promise from Chimene and his closest friends that they will bind him upright on his horse and, with his king beside him, he will ride out at the head of his soldiers the following morning...<br /><br />As dawn breaks and the Spanish troops are maintaining steady their position, waiting inside the gates in silence as their leaders rides through upright and firm of face, the gates of the city swing open and the rays of the sun transmit their sparkling light over the Spanish hero... Their lances and helmets emit a source of energy as the white-bearded warrior, on his white stallion, rides out the gates of history and into legends... Miklos Rozsa's organ raised more the exaltation for these great images were themselves mythical...<br /><br />In Rodrigo's character we discover great qualities of an unusual man: He is merciful and courageous, a man of honor, a great champion... B000ICL3KG|3.0|The lecture portions of Gore's presentation are compelling and well worth viewing, if only for the knowledge presented therein.  The remainder, which combines biographical moments from Gore's life played a little too much like one of the candidate bio films played at political conventions.  Thanks to modern technology those parts are easy to fast forward through and thus do not detract at all from the lecture portions -- which are compelling.  The best part is the timeline -- which is the one part I showed to my 11 year old that convinced him utterly. <br /> <br />Gore also does a wonderful job of demonstrating how absurd \\"conventional wisdom\\" can be -- without ever taking the scientific establishment head on -- he takes a great example from his youth (and mine) when our grade school teachers (and approved textbooks) completely ruled out the notion that the continents actually fit together at one time, despite the coincidental similarities in coastlines. <br /> <br />Gore's recommendations as to what to do about the problems he identified are thoughtprovoking in unusual ways.  How to deal with this \\"uncomfortable truth\\" without surrendering to despair or helplessness?  This may be as inevitable as plate tectonics!! <br /> <br /> Here's a man who was both Senator and Vice President, ran for President, and was utterly unable to do anything about it -- now he is doing the only thing he can think of, which is to go out and present these facts one lecture at a time.  What can the rest of us do about it?  And will it matter?  Maybe -- but for my money we will see the polar bear go the way of the passenger pigeon long before we come up with any solution. <br /> <br />

B00006CXSS|5.0|I bought this for my father, a WWII infantry vet who saw action (and won a bronze star with a purple heart) in the battle of the bulge -- (he was, in fact, among the first people to see the Russian Cossakss invade Poland from the East on his 13th birthday in 1939  <br /> <br />He watches little TV, and has little interest in DVD's.  Doesn't see a lot of WWII stuff -- he was mesmerized and watched it all the way through several times.  Actively avoids it at time. This presentation rang very true to him and perhaps even spoke to him.  (My son and I have watched it many times, in both the HBO and A&E incarnations). <br /> <br />Based upon Ambrose's wonderful oral history of an elite light infantry company in WWII (and its leadership) the production values are simply outstanding, and it communicates a sensibility about the war that rings true to all ages -- from 10 to 85.   I personally found the series to be uneven, and lacking in continuity, principally because the medium required a focus upon different characters in different episodes and, since it was based upon real events, there are necessary gaps in continuity.  Simply read Ambrose's book, and those problems are readily solved. <br /> <br />It is difficult to identify a comparable movie or miniseries -- perhaps Stone's Platoon (which combined the real horror with the real bonds that formed amongst the men who fought) comes closest.  After that, the \\"Combat\\" TV series (written by men who had served in WWII is the closest analogy one can think of.   <br /> <br />For those without cable, and any interest in WWII or combat, this is a must own.
