0140187537|5.0|When John Steinbeck won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1962, many felt that this book was what reminded the Prize committee of Steinbeck's greatness. Like all of his books, short stories and non-fiction journalism, this is very well written, has developed characters who readers will recognize and presents a useful moral at the end. This might be his most modern and recognizable story, however.<br /><br />Ethan Hawley is the well educated scion of a prominent Long Island family that has fallen on hard times and has lost its place at the top of society. Ethan is known throughout the community for his honesty and integrity, but there is pressure from everyone--his family, his boss, friends and local big wigs--for him to sacrifice his morales to earn a better living and make a name for himself. As he struggles with the temptation of a big pay day, he develops a plan which will destroy his own standards of decency, but will elevate his family back into the prestigious position he thinks they deserve.<br /><br />The story is well told and engaging, plus it gives readers a great opportunity to decide whether the modern society Steinbeck sees is really worth the price it costs. I would highly recommend this book to Steinbeck fans or people who enjoy good writing and stories that make them think.
0307341542|4.0|Wind Gap, Missouri; not a town to draw the attention of a big city newspaper.  The story of the abduction and murder of two young girls from Camille Preaker's home town isn't enough to wish her back there in her wildest dreams but unfortunately, her boss thinks otherwise.  The Chicago Daily Post needs a headline piece, badly, that is going to come out of the corner and kill the masses.  Editor Frank Curry has always had a strange kind of faith in his favourite reporter.  Camille is sure it's entirely misplaced but as she wants to please the man who was there for her in a dark time, she heads back to where her screwed up little life all began. <br />  <br />The abattoir and processing factory that still largely supports Wind Gap unfairly hasn't left a porcine stink on it's owner, Camille's genteel mother Adora, a whimsical and earnest person who was only ever happy when her children desperately needed her.  Camille feels it should have, as should have the circumstances of her birth with there still being a big fat question mark as to the identity of her father.  Adora still reigns, over her house, her family, and her town.  Camille's half sister is disturbingly like her mother in some ways, and reminds her of her own self in others.  The thirteen year old Amma dominates her fearsome little group of four like little blondes and is doing a damn fine job of doing the same to the residents of Wind Gap.  Finding it hard not to get sucked back into old, dark habits, Camille cozies up a little too much to the Kansas hot shot cop sent in to help out the police in the little backwater.  It seems her new partner has already made up his mind on this one, along with most of the town, that only a newcomer to Wind Gap could be evil enough to inflict so much on innocents who little deserved it.   <br />  <br />SHARP OBJECTS: a nasty little piece in the most delightful way.  Where would the creepiest thrillers go without turning to dysfunctional families that make our own look pretty good?  Okay, so writer Gillian Flynn all but bludgeons us about the head in pointing out the villain of the hour, very EARLY in the hour.  This seems to be the main complaint with this read; otherwise, it is very difficult to find anything to criticize in this polished debut novel.  <br />  <br />How refreshing to have the investigating protagonist not always operating from the moral high ground.  We mystery readers like our heroes somewhat brooding and damaged and the package here is the modern woman's version of just that.  With so much to hide of her own self and with not wanting to confront what's left behind, Camille Preaker's viewpoint of the proceedings is completely immersed in the swamp that is her own family.  The incestuous small town of Camille's childhood and its people are all in the murk with her.  The heavy, oppressive air that permeates this read is almost a tangible thing and if you're looking for hope and redemption with your mystery, you'd best look elsewhere than at this disturbing thriller.  SHARP OBJECTS pleases in an almost visceral way and revolts as it reveals; strange to think that one novel can do both.  Gillian Flynn has achieved much with SHARP OBJECTS and as much as it is a first attempt on the market, it is also quite the attack. <br />
1594200823|5.0|This is the best book I've consumed in a long time, and I recommend it highly. This is a great dissertation on food: where it comes from, how we relate to it, what it really costs us. He analyzes the sources of four meals as produced by the industrial food, industrial organic, artisanal farmer, and hunter/gatherer systems. Perhaps the highest compliments I can pay: it is deeply thought provoking; it will change the way I buy my food. <br /> <br />While there are a few moments when the author strays over the line and becomes a polemicist using literary and logical tricks to sway your thinking, that is not the basic tenor or thrust. His fundamental approach is to show you what is really there, so you are aware of what's really going on, and then you can make your own choices based on knowledge. Quibble as you will over the quality of research, the details of particular points, his attitude or approach on a particular subtopic. Thinking people can think, and this book gives you much to think about. This is not a vegan diatribe, or a PETA \\"animals are people too\\" broadside. It is a reasoned and intelligent recounting of one man's search for understanding, brilliantly told and beautifully written.  <br /> <br />If you wish to remain blissfully ignorant about something as fundamental as the food you eat, do not read this book. If you like to know what's going on around you, then this book is a real eye opener.

B000A59PMO|5.0|Veronica Mars is about a girl who is about 10 times smarter, sharp witted, and drama filled than anyone else around her, (not to mention she is 10 times prettier than everyone else).  She never fails to deliver a quick witted response to peoples slanders against her.  There is no case to hard, no villain to horrific, no relationship too broken to knock her off her feet.  The show is basically about a murder involving her best friend.  The mystery holds well, as do all the cases-of-the-week which never fail to involve great amounts of thought, no matter how silly the are.  The writing is as sharp as Kristen Bell's performance.  She can go from innocent teen one moment, to sarcastic know it all the next, to bubble head the next, to broken hearted girl on her own with an amazing ease.  The only problem with the show in general are the relationship plot lines.<br /><br />Beware of spoiler:<br />The Logan, Duncan, police man triangle is very weak, especially the break up scenes with the police man.  They way that is resolved makes this show almost of 4 star show.  I have never in my life seen such a terrible resolve.  On the other hand, the Logan relationship is bizarre and never really is believable.  Veronica and Logan have chemistry, but not in a romantic way.  Their chemistry is from the contestant arguing.  Duncan and Veronica have a mild but believable chemistry.  The policeman, who gets very little screen time, seems to be the one that she has the most chemistry with, making is almost impossible to believe that she would dump him.<br /><br />end of spoiler<br /><br />with that downfall, the show still gets a five stars because of the great season finale.  The guilty person is not the one I would have ever thought it was, and the cliff hanger, while a little set-up-for-next-seasons-mystery less, is not all that bad.  The show is fresh in this world of the same ol thing every week.  I hope it doesn't get cancelled.
0684857219|2.0|This is a great workout book if you have nothing else to do but workout. The routines in this book are quite effective but they are also long and demand much of your time. I can't workout like I once did. I can't eat like I once did. I can't do a lot of things like I once did. But I'm still in good shape. If for some reason I can't go to the gym one day, I don't beat myself up over it, I'll do some \\"invisible training\\". You might laugh at this, but I \\"pretend\\" I'm lifting an imaginary weight. In my mind, I pick out an exercise, let's say dumbell presses. I see a 50lb weight in each hand and I go through all the straining, all the effort as if those weights were actually in my hand. After the seventh rep, I'm breaking a sweat, after ten reps, I'm exhausted. I'll do some \\"pretend\\" laterals, same thing, some \\"imaginary\\" upright rows, all for 3 sets of ten and y'know what? My shoulders are just as pumped up if I had gone to the gym.<br /><br />Arnold has always had kind of an \\"excessive\\" philosophy about training, anyway. If two hours is good, four must be better. If ten sets per body part does the trick, than thirty sets will make the results come three times faster. If you're young and enthused and inspired, go knock yourself out, but if you're approaching middle age or are already there, don't kid yourself...please, just don't. Go workout. Have fun. 0618680004|1.0|Many years ago when I read the short volume by atheist Bertrand Russell, Why I Am Not a Christian, I thought: there is not much substance to this. Generalisations, straw men, red herrings and misrepresentations seemed to characterise the book. Dawkins' book is longer, more sophisticated and more comprehensive, but it bears the same traits as found in Russell's l927 tract.<br /><br />Indeed, there are atheists and there are atheists. The garden-variety don't like religion, don't like God and don't like people who do. Then there is the especially hard-core variety. These are atheists who are on a mission, an evangelistic crusade to save the world from religion. They hate religion and are convinced it must be eradicated at all costs. Such atheists have every bit as much zeal and fanaticism in their secular jihad as a religious person ever will. Richard Dawkins is a classic example of the atheist storm-trooper.<br /><br />His newest book continues his passionate crusade to rid the world of every last vestige of religion. For in Dawkins' eyes, religion is the source of all evil, while atheism is the path of enlightenment, brotherhood and liberation. One is either a blind, ignorant fool who is overwhelmed by delusion, or one sees the light through the lens of atheism.<br /><br />Dawkins is contemptuous of all religions, so he is an equal opportunity offender. But it is Christianity that he especially savages. He says that the Bible is \\"just plain weird\\" and \\"systematically evil\\". He speaks of God's acts as \\"God's jealous sulk,\\" \\"God's maniacal jealousy,\\" \\"ethnic cleansing\\" and \\"genocide\\". Yahweh is simply a \\"cruel ogre\\" and a \\"monster\\" according to Dawkins.<br /><br />But wait, there's more. Dawkins calls the atoning death of Christ \\"vicious, sado-masochistic and repellent,\\" and \\"morally obnoxious\\". So much for tolerance and open-mindedness.<br /><br />In Dawkins' view religion is the source of all evil, while atheism is the source of all sweetness and light. Never minds the millions of people killed in the name of atheistic utopias, be they Stalin's, Hitler's or Mao's.<br /><br />For all of his hatred of Christianity, Dawkins has to go much further if he wants to offer an intellectually satisfying debunking of this faith. His arguments are simply shallow and unconvincing. They are also poorly argued, with hardly any substantial documentation or evidence.<br /><br />At most, his arguments tell us more about his own twisted temperament, and his anti-Christian bigotry. They certainly do not offer us a telling critique of the Christian faith.<br /><br />Consider Dawkins' use of the term delusion. Not only is this not much of an argument, but if every time I spoke about atheists, and simply dismissed their claims as mere delusion, they would not think I was advancing much of a case. And they would be right. So in a sense this book is one long exercise in the fallacy known as ad hominem. Simply attacking the person and thinking you have won the argument.<br /><br />Of course by delusion he has certain ideas in mind. Dawkins holds to the standard worldview of the philosophical naturalist, which seeks to make a disjunction between faith and reason, religion and science. Science gives us truth, but faith is simply myth. But more sober minds on both sides of the debate recognise these to be false polarisations. Faith, at least in the Christian religion, is informed by reason. It may at times go beyond reason, but it does not run counter to it.<br /><br />And the scientific enterprise is also characterised by faith commitment. There are all kinds of unproven assumptions and presuppositions which may or may not be testable. The myth of complete scientific neutrality and objectivity has been countered by many important thinkers.<br /><br />But because of Dawkins' pre-commitment to philosophical naturalism, he rules our a priori any possibility of the supernatural. And anyone who does seek to escape the narrow confines of such naturalism (the idea that only matter matters) is, according to Dawkins, simply deluded.<br /><br />Thus by Dawkins' chosen framework, anyone who disagrees with him must be living in delusion. But his worldview, which is born not of scientific evidence, but philosophical commitment, itself can be challenged. A good critique of Dawkins in this regard can be found in Alister McGrath's recent book, Dawkins' God.<br /><br />Dawkins' acerbic attack of the faith of billions of people comes across as just another fundamentalist crusade or jihad. It is just as intolerant and judgmental as any religious broadside can be.<br /><br />The author's over-reliance on ad hominem, name-calling, red herrings, straw men, and selective use of evidence makes this book unconvincing at best and repellent at worst. Indeed, if anything, this book has all the hallmarks of what it claims is wrong with religionists: it is just too doctrinaire, arrogant, intolerant, bigoted, narrow-minded, and full of pomposity and venom.<br /><br />There certainly are more cogent and telling arguments that can be advanced against religious belief. But the reader will have to look elsewhere for them. This book succeeds in doing only one job well: showing us the arrogance and narrow-mindedness of militant atheism.<br /><br />With the brisk sales of this book, its author should be making quite a few quid. However it is the reader who is being short-changed. For a book that is meant to be an intellectual \\"case\\" against God and belief, this book comes nowhere close to demonstrating the irrationality of religious belief. It seems instead to demonstrate the bitterness and paucity of thinking of at least one famous atheist.uch naturalism (the idea that only matter matters) is, according to Dawkins, simply deluded. <br /> <br />Thus by Dawkins' chosen framework, anyone who disagrees with him must be living in delusion. But his worldview, which is born not of scientific evidence, but philosophical commitment, itself can be challenged. A good critique of Dawkins in this regard can be found in Alister McGrath's recent book, Dawkins' God.  <br /> <br />Dawkins' acerbic attack of the faith of billions of people comes across as just another fundamentalist crusade or jihad. It is just as intolerant and judgmental as any religious broadside can be. <br /> <br />The author's over-reliance on ad hominem, name-calling, red herrings, straw men, and selective use of evidence makes this book unconvincing at best and repellent at worst. Indeed, if anything, this book has all the hallmarks of what it claims is wrong with religionists: it is just too doctrinaire, arrogant, intolerant, bigoted, narrow-minded, and full of pomposity and venom. <br /> <br />There certainly are more cogent and telling arguments that can be advanced against religious belief. But the reader will have to look elsewhere for them. This book succeeds in doing only one job well: showing us the arrogance and narrow-mindedness of militant atheism. <br /> <br />With the brisk sales of this book, its author should be making quite a few quid. However it is the reader who is being short-changed. For a book that is meant to be an intellectual \\"case\\" against God and belief, this book comes nowhere close to demonstrating the irrationality of religious belief. It seems instead to demonstrate the bitterness and paucity of thinking of at least one famous atheist.
6305558167|4.0|Along with Ken Russell, John Boorman can be seen as a key figure in the modern British cinema... His interest in myth, dream, landscape and memory may be compared with that of Resnais, Leone, and Roeg...<br /><br />Boorman's 'Excalibur' is characterized by his use of jealousy and adultery, sex and sorcery... It is also characterized by fire and fog, shadow and moonlight, creating an air of mystery that is essential element in the Arthurian legend...<br /><br />Boorman's 'Excalibur' is a mythical presentation leading the viewers to travel with the flow of the legend... It is a magical story with wonderful exotic sets, and interesting camera-work in the lush green scenery of Ireland... (The Cinematography won an Academy Award Nomination).<br /><br />Boorman's \\"Excalibur\\" is both fantasy and philosophy... Love seems to be a destructive force, lyrically beautiful and bravely realistic...<br /><br />The film brings to life the fateful story of a solitary hero, his ascension to the throne, the love triangle of Camelot, the quest for the Holy Grail, the decline and eventual fall of Arthur and Camelot... Along for the ride are his indispensable Knights of the Round Table, particularly Sir Lancelot...<br /><br />The characters in Boorman's \\"Excalibur\\" are extremely well developed... Arthur is seen as a naive squire, who develops into an idealistic king... Arthur tries to use Might for the establishment of Right, and according to his own laws, he puts reason over love...<br /><br />A prominent figure in the film is Merlin... He lives backwards, which makes him \\"a dream to some, a nightmare to others.\\" He defines the cave of the dragon as a place where all things meet their opposite: \\"The future and the past, desire and regret, knowledge and oblivion\\". But when Morgana pronounces \\"love\\", one would expect Merlin to answer \\"hate\\", but he just says: \\"O yes.\\"<br /><br />Morgana knows that Uther and Merlin are responsible for the death of her father... She dedicates her life to revenge.. Her scenes with Merlin are full of fire and poison... When she steals the \\"charm of making\\" from Merlin, Morgana gets stronger... We feared her lines when she affirmed: \\"I can ease your loneliness.\\"<br /><br />Lancelot looks at himself as a sinful person who has betrayed a friend... He stays lonely in the forest, haunted by sorrow and pain... He dreams of a fight with himself... And when he wakes up naked, he sees his own sword stuck in his side... The film endures and inspires because it embodies mankind's deepest yearnings...<br /><br />Among the many elements that make the movie work is the cast: Nigel Terry, the rightful King who, accidentally, removes the sword of power easily, not once, but twice; Helen Mirren, the enchantress Morgana, Merlin's nemesis and Arthur's treacherous half-sister, who seduces Merlin, and then encircles him in a stream of vengeance; Nicholas Clay, persuasively ardent and athletic as the First Knight; Cherie Lunghi, the damsel in distress who loves her husband with her mind and Lancelot with her heart; Nicol Williamson, the wily Merlin who would see that the young Arthur receive the necessary training and guidance to fulfill his unlikely destiny; Gabriel Byrne, the hot-blooded Uther Pendragon, who plunges 'Excalibur' deep into a stone rock in one last act of defiance; Katrine Boorman, the woman taken as by a fully armored King; Liam Neeson, the knight who dares to accuse the Queen; and Robert Addie, the 'unholy child' who comes to Camelot to demand the throne of his father...<br /><br />One of the more fascinating aspects of the film (and there are many...) are the differences between Uther and Arthur... King Uther is unable to master his instincts... His world is confusion, disorder, and unlimited passion... The characteristic developments of Arthur occur as he faces the trials of his life... The knowledge of the affair yet his love for his beautiful wife and best friend wage war inside of his mind... When he sees Guinevere in the arms of Lancelot, he stuck 'Excalibur' between them loosing his connection to the extraordinary powers of Merlin and the Lady of the Lake...<br /><br />John Boorman's films frequently concern contradictions and polarities, tensions between nature and civilization, dream and reality... In the early 70s amidst the quagmire of Vietnam, the civil rights movement and the corruption of the Nixon administration the cinema produced Planet of the Apes, Soylent Green and THX 1138. It is without a doubt the best film of 2006.

Ergo, this review is suited more for those who have never read a Bukowski novel (a couple of poems don't count).  If you read this you need to be the type of person who doesn't take yourself and the world too seriously.  Otherwise, odds are you will be disgusted with Bukowski as a whole and dislike all of his novels.  Because unlike anyone I have ever read Bukowski is what he writes!  And what he writes about isn't pretty, it isn't politically correct, it isn't nice, it isn't tasteful or tactful, it isn't informative, it doesn't have meaning, etc... do I need to say more?  What it is, is real and gritty and funny and raw and honest and brave.  This guy can write like nobody's business and as much as you need to hate and pity him you just can't help but like and admire him at the same time.  The fact that Bukowski is so much more popular in Europe than he is in his home country would make for great coffee house debate (not that I ever have or as fun as it sounds ever will).  Perhaps his poking fun at the American way of life, that it wasn't all Norman Rockwell, Howdy Doody, Ozzie & Harriet bull.... like it tried to portray itself back then (many may argue that it still does today) in the early days of TV, radio, newspapers, etc...  Perhaps people in Europe see something romantic about an iconoclastic writer that doesn't have the same value system as the average Capitalist(myself included).  The good, old red blooded American automaton marching off dutifully to work everyday.  Perhaps in Europe they aren't as uptight with sex or politically correctness as the vapid Religious Right and the pretentious libs in this country are.  I don't really know, I just know that I really like this guy warts and all.  Forgive me father, for I have sinned.ountry are. B00005JPCA|5.0|Before I start, I won't get all technical here with the film and unfold all of its nuances because many people have already done so, and I won't ruin the movie for anyone either. All of this is my own opinion of the film. This movie teaches you who James Bond is as a spy and as a person, and after you have seen it, you'll understand exactly why the world's coolest fictional spy is who he is.    Casino Royale is definitely the best Bond film in at least 10 years (if not my favourite one of all time). Yes, I too was upset when Pierce Brosnan was kicked off the series and I was a bit shocked when I found out that some blonde British guy was taking Brosnan's place, but honestly, it never really bothered me at all. Actually, I think I forgot about the whole thing. But now that I have seen Casino Royale, I do believe that Daniel Craig did an amazing job portraying Bond. I don't care about the way he looks (even though I think he's quite beautiful). Looks are not the most important thing. He's a great actor with the passion and the attitude that has been missing for so long. He defeated the stereotype for how James Bond should look and act, and for that he gets my approval and admiration. He was made to play this role. Go see his last two films if you don't believe me.     I went into the movie with an open mind and was completely hooked when the opening riff to \\"You Know My Name\\" started, and I wasn't disappointed for a moment after. James Bond wasn't a sophisticated and seasoned spy yet in this story, which is how he should be considering the context of the movie, when he first receives his license to kill and 00 status and starts his tenure as a spy. You would expect him to go on some sort of an ego trip and to not have all of these fancy gadgets floating around everywhere. If those were inserted into the movie, the movie would be too gaudy and parody-like. I think they captured the essence of who he was at the beginning and I loved every minute of Bond being a reckless, chauvinistic, egotistical s.o.b. The one-liners were great and I also really loved the romance between James and Vesper. We actually saw the emotional lovey-dovey side of James Bond in this film. He loved Vesper and Vesper loved him back...but Vesper Lynd really is James Bond's one and only true love and that's never changed in the last 21 films.    The movie was carried out perfectly, from the opening scenes and credits, to the theme song (which I love), and to the very end, which will keep you wondering. They definitely needed to save the Bond franchise after \\"Die Another Day\\" and they nailed it. I hope that Daniel Craig keeps playing Bond for a while because I will be sad to see him go. His work here has made a fan out of me and I cannot wait to see him in other films, Bond or not. The acting was superb by every cast member as well. If this movie doesn't get some award by the American or international motion picture community, then I'll be disappointed.    My only gripes with the film are that it was one big advertisement for Sony. Now, I love Sony products, but even though they own the rights to this movie, they did not need to pull the desperate plug and put all of their electronic devices in the film. They make enough money as it is. My next gripe is with Eva Green's makeup. She's a beautiful girl, but she doesn't need all that black eye makeup around her eyes. She looked just fine without all that black stuff. My last gripe comes with everybody comparing this movie to the Bourne series. This is not the Bourne Identity or the Bourne Supremacy, and even though there are a few similarities, these two movies are different and should be kept that way. It would have been really awesome also if this movie was set in the 1950's. It would have been true to the book and when this was originally written. That would have been an interesting experience.    I completely suggest that you go see this film. If you're not a Bond addict yet, this is the perfect intro to whathappens in the beginning and how things came to be. Then start watching all the movies and read the books if you're inclined to do so. (Read the books first...they're great and help you understand what happens in the movies.) If you're looking for a movie with crazy gadgets, bad jokes/sexual innuendo, unrealistic plots/villians, and a spy who acts like a pretty boy and eats caviar, this may not be the movie you are looking for. If you're looking for a modern and fresh James Bond with attitude and using his brains to get the mission completed, then by all means go see the movie...now.     I hope this review helps you to make some judgement on this film.

1400032717|5.0|So much has been written about this book that it is hard to come up with original ways of describing the genius of it. So, I will pretend that you know nothing about it. The book starts with a murder... the murder of a neighborhood dog. The narrator of the book is falsely accused of being the killer so he decides to solve the crime and discover the true perpetrator. It doesn't sound too interesting except that the narrator of the story is a 16-year old autistic boy by the name of Christopher Boone. Christopher decides to both solve the crime and write about his investigation in a book for a school project.<br /><br />Solving the crime will be difficult for Christopher for several reasons related to his autism. He is unable to understand why people react the way they do. He can't decode metaphors such as I laughed my head off, since the person still has their head. He can't look at people and use their facial expressions as a clue to what they are saying. He becomes overwhelmed by strangers, crowds, loud noises, and being touched and throws himself on the floor, rocking and moaning when he feels overwhelmed. But solving the mystery is only part of the story as Christopher's investigation reveals something else that he could never have expected.<br /><br />The story itself is a framework that Haddon uses to show what autism might feel like from inside the mind of an autistic person. There is a logic to the mind of Christopher and by using the first person Haddon makes Christopher a believable and understandable and sympathetic character. This makes even the common place become engrossing as we struggle with Christopher to perform the simplest of tasks. For example, buying a ticket and getting on a train becomes a page-turner as Christopher struggles with crowds and noises and smells.<br /><br />Haddon has written a brilliant novel that has that rare quality of being worth re-reading. I don't know if this book actually reflects the mind of a person with autism but I do know that it is thoroughly fascinating, unique, and enjoyable. I can strongly recommend this book.t I do know that it is thoroughly fascinating, unique, and enjoyable. I can strongly recommend this book.

B00000K3CK|3.0|'Miracle on 34th Street' is still an enduring holiday movie.  There is a lot of novelty to draw upon.  A man from a nursing home takes over the Santa helm at Macy's Department store and has all the charm and warmth to replace his drunken predecessor in a pinch. He's liked well enough until he takes the role seriously enough to proclaim he is 'the' Santa Claus and even writes it on his job form.  Although endearing, he alarms his employer who objects when he insists to his daughter (Natalie Wood, who looks the same when she's grown up, only smaller) that Santa is the real and he's the real McCoy.  The cynical won't have it, and Macy's psychiatrist and a local politician behind the judge (William Frawley, later Fred of 'I Love Lucy' fame) analyse the situation until it becomes a ticklish affair among the press.  With some realistic acting by key players and a fun premise that is both fanciful and true-to-life, 'Miracle on 34th Street' is believable enough to keep us all going.

It's about 2 hours long in length but it feels like an hour. It shows how kids were broken down and built back up into killing machines. Some of the things they say can be disturbing when describing their rifle. The movie will often shock you, make you laugh, and depress you. Lee Ermey will blow you away with his role as Gunny Hartman the drill sargent. <br /> <br />Visually, this is a so-so picture. While most of the film has a decent clarity, there is also an undeniable amount of grain during parts of the film. This isn't because it's an HD DVD, it's also the same case with the Blu-Ray version.  HD DVD's have an incredible reputation with visual clarity, Blu-Ray on the other hand... well, I suppose this title fits in perfectly with other Blu-Ray movies when it comes to visual clarity. Warner Brothers could have done more than they did, perhaps in the distant future it'll be revisited. However, since the film is so good and absorbing and finally seeing it in Widescreen with some high definition at all makes it an incredible experience. <br /> <br />Overall, if you're just getting an HD DVD player all I can say is that there's many other titles that have a groundbreaking showcase of high definition BUT if you want a movie that's truly a classic and will blow you away with the lack of real visual clarity at times, this movie is it.

0618680004|2.0|Clearly Dawkins no longer feels the need to mask his own personal convictions wholly under the guise of \\"objective science.\\" In this book, Dawkins lays bare the engine that has driven and inspired his entire life work - his own personal ideologies and subjective beliefs.     We're talking here about belief in answers to life's deeper questions and issues - the nature of reality, the purpose of life, the existence of God. After reading this book it is now easier to accept that many of Dawkins' previous bold statements, such as \\"the survival of DNA is the ultimate rational for our existence\\" (River Out of Eden, 1996), are not scientific statements at all. Rather, they are Dawkins' own subjective views - held in Dawkins' mind with equal zeal as a religious fundamentalist.     Conclusions regarding the purpose or non-purpose of life, or relating to why the universe is here in the first place, are based on philosophical ideologies - answers reached beyond the scope of science. Dawkins has always cheekily stepped over this line by (con)fusing scientific enquiry with his own subjective beliefs. But in `the God Delusion', Dawkins hurls himself over the line completely, unashamedly declaring his views that there is no purpose to the cosmos, that God does not exist, and that nothing continues beyond the veil of death.    Dawkins' case against the existence of God in this book is actually an enormous straw man argument. He identifies God exclusively with the narrow religious `fundamentalist' point of view, undermines it, and concludes that anyone who believes in God is therefore intellectually bankrupt. Yet Dawkins seems unaware that his argument against this narrow interpretation of life and God leaves only fertile ground for a more spiritually mature religious point of view, which I'm sure will rise in the popular mind as the human race evolves.    In our finite, human state, I believe that we must learn to discern the difference between the cleverness of the head and the wisdom of the heart. Science is the tool by which we can explore and describe the physical world. But we must begin to tune into our inner-intuition and spiritual awareness in order to discern answers to life's deeper questions and mysteries.     Dawkins believes that all theists and religionists are slow-witted. However, as humanity evolves, human consciousness will surely continue to expand, and a new frame of reference and state of awareness will likely change our entire perspective on everything. Clearly, our religious mythologies are mankind's early attempts to describe cosmic events of which the human mind can barely conceive, but of which the soul is deeply aware. To interpret such tales and mythologies as literal scientific accounts, as Dawkins insists upon doing, is to miss the point completely. I believe that people throughout the ages have already attained a mature degree of spiritual awareness, and such states of consciousness will eventually grow and become embedded in the popular mind. Humanity will then be deluded no more.

B000JVT1U0|4.0|`The Wicker Man' done originally in 1974 is a great English cult film, similar in many ways to the earlier English film version of William Golding's high school favorite novel, `Lord of the Flies'. And, just like `Lord of the Flies', we are now treated to a Hollywood remake of this classic with co-producer Nicholas Cage in the lead role created by Australian actor, Edward Woodward in the original flick.<br /><br />I am happy to say that the remake of `The Wicker Man' is better than the remake of `Lord of the Flies', where the filmmakers seemed to totally miss the point of Golding's story. The new `The Wicker Man' did change a fair amount of the story, but largely what was really essential to moving the scene from an island off Scotland to an American island in Washington State, in Puget Sound.<br /><br />The primary problem faced by the filmmakers is that in the original story, much was made of the traditional English class system with a traditional Manor House landlord, emphasis on the `lord' business in charge of the `private island' with an otherwise very peculiar social system. The modern storytellers got a lot of mileage out of their paradigm shift from English noble to cult matriarch at the head of a little society patterned after the society of bees, which happens to also be the island's main industry, replacing the orchard agriculture in the English original. These changes are to the good. The only problem with the switch from apples to bees is that while apples are not normally grown on the Scottish islands, bees are not at all out of place in Puget Sound. This looses a useful clue to the unusual nature of this island community.<br /><br /> Another fairly effective change is to make the lead character policeman (Cage) allergic to bee stings. Somewhat less effective is providing the California policeman with a back story which connects him to a resident of the Summersisle community (The modern movie adds an extra `s' to aid in pronouncing the name), making him the father of the missing little girl, the bait which the mother uses to draw cop Cage to the island.<br /><br />I think the problem with this backstory is that while Cage and Woodward are both playing policemen, Cage is out of his jurisdiction and his police authority is really a shadow with no real weight. Woodward, on the other hand, has official standing on his island and is fully authorized to make arrests and conduct investigations.<br /><br />Otherwise, the story plays out in almost exactly parallel scenes starting at the point at which Cage arrives at on the island.<br /><br />The original movie had a purely realistic story, where the only supernatural element was in the island inhabitants' beliefs. There were no supernatural threats and not even too many menacing flashbacks or dreams. The remake remained true to this point of view, and improved on it just a bit by drawing parallels between the Summersisle community and the Amish, where both exhibited anti-technological biases. I think I also saw a hint of parallel being drawn to the puritan witches of Salem, Massachusetts.<br /><br />Of course, nature was called in to help out by blanking out cell phone reception on the island. One problem both movies shared is that they were marketed as `horror' movies. While the sense of threat is constant throughout most of the movie, it is not really the kind of supernatural threat we get in most Stephen King stories. Like `Psycho' and `Ten Little Indians', the source of threat is entirely based on purely human, albeit quite pathological, behavior. The isolated venue does create similarities with stories such as `Alien' and `House on Haunted Hill' where the victim(s) are physically cut off from any outside help, but here, the primary thing keeping Cage / Woodward on the island is the obsession with the lost girl. I also note a strong similarity with the movie `Don't Look Now' where the plot is driven by fleeting glimpses of a little lost girl.<br /><br />In the end,the modern `The Wicker Man' makes the Summersisle inhabitants just a bit more loony and therefore just a bit less believable in their realistic setting. While one can easily imagine descendants of Druids celebrating May Day with animalistic costumes, neither the Amish nor a hippie holdover connection works quite as well. Too bad cinema finances prevented the filmmakers from keeping the venue back in the old country. While Cage is a superb actor, I think Woodward's matter of fact, `just the facts, Madam' tone of the English constable fits against the background of the tree worshipping islanders. The islanders don't have to be quite so bizarre to stand out behind Woodward's low-key tone. This also means that the original movie gives much less away early on. The unraveling of the threat and the climax comes more slowly and subtly. But when it does, it's a far bigger surprise.<br /><br />Last but not least, I think the current director, Neil LaBute, should have studied the camera work on the last scene of the original more carefully. The original director did a much better job of revealing the climax venue, even in black and white.<br /><br />So, while Cage is ultimately a more interesting actor than Woodward, I would still recommend the original over the remake if what you want is a really good rendition of the story. I will say that the modern `The Wicker Man' has my favorite DVD extra, a commentary soundtrack including the director, editor, and a few of the lesser actors (I think casting Ellen Burstyn was a waste of her talent. They did such a good job of casting the minor women on the island, but Burstyn just didn't seem to work as the queen bee.). This commentary easily doubles the value of the DVD. The `shocking Alternate Ending' is just a bit more graphic violence added to the telling of the final scene, which adds nothing to the meat of the story.r />In the end, the modern `The Wicker Man' makes the Summersisle inhabitants just a bit more loony and therefore just a bit less believable in their realistic setting. While one can easily imagine descendants of Druids celebrating May Day with animalistic costumes, neither the Amish nor a hippie holdover connection works quite as well. Too bad cinema finances prevented the filmmakers from keeping the venue back in the old country. While Cage is a superb actor, I think Woodward's matter of fact, `just the facts, Madam' tone of the English constable fits against the background of the tree worshipping islanders. The islanders don't have to be quite so bizarre to stand out behind Woodward's low-key tone. This also means that the original movie gives much less away early on. The unraveling of the threat and the climax comes more slowly and subtly. But when it does, it's a far bigger surprise. <br /> <br />Last but not least, I think the current director, Neil LaBute, should have studied the camera work on the last scene of the original more carefully. The original director did a much better job of revealing the climax venue, even in black and white. <br /> <br />So, while Cage is ultimately a more interesting actor than Woodward, I would still recommend the original over the remake if what you want is a really good rendition of the story. I will say that the modern `The Wicker Man' has my favorite DVD extra, a commentary soundtrack including the director, editor, and a few of the lesser actors (I think casting Ellen Burstyn was a waste of her talent. They did such a good job of casting the minor women on the island, but Burstyn just didn't seem to work as the queen bee.). This commentary easily doubles the value of the DVD. The `shocking Alternate Ending' is just a bit more graphic violence added to the telling of the final scene, which adds nothing to the meat of the story. <br />
B000K4WPCC|5.0|This supernatural thriller was a feast for the eyes, in more ways than one. The subject matter and mythology surrounding witchcraft is fascinating, and provides an intriguing background for this movie. The special effects are breathtaking and intense, and (I'm not going to lie) it doesn't hurt that the male leads are all pretty easy on the eyes.<br /><br />The details of the story are difficult to explain without giving too much away. Caleb and his friends are whats known as the Sons of Ipswich. They are the first born sons of the five founding families of their town in Massechusetts. In the past, during the notorious witch hunt in Massechusetts, their families were all accused of practicing witchcraft....and their accusers were right. Caleb and his friends each possess powers and supernatural abilities beyond anything you've ever seen. When they turn 18, their powers will reach their peak potential, and they will \\"ascend\\". But as in all things in nature, there is a delicate balance that must be maintained, and these powers come with a price.<br /><br />I enjoyed this film mostly for the ridiculously awesome special effects. From a cinematography standpoint, it's very well made, and if for nothing else, at least watch this movie once to see all the cool things they do with camera angles and special effects.<br /><br />One of the things I liked most about this film was it's use of witchcraft mythology. Instead of the usual witchraft movies, such as \\"The Craft\\", this one used males instead of females as it's main characters/witches (I think that makes them warlocks). I found the backstory of their covenant almost more interesting than the present day story they were trying to tell. I wanted to hear more! I truly hope they make a sequel so that we can hear more witchcraft mythology, because I find it very fascinating.<br /><br />Admittedly, the guys who play the lead characters *do* look like they walked right off the pages of an Abercrombie and Fitch catalog...but why is it such a bad thing that they're good looking? I just thought I should have full disclosure on this issue). The lead's acting abilities also occassionally waiver (thats what happens when you use unknowns in movies) but it's not enough to warrent a big tirade. The story is still entertaining, and the characters do well with what they are given.<br /><br />Also...there is definitely an abundance of girls running around in their underwear, so men shouldn't be complaining so much.<br /><br />Bottom line, this movie is definitely worth checking out for it's awesome special effects, wicked cool music score, great eye candy, and intricate mythologically based storyline...but why is it such a bad thing that they're good looking? I just thought I should have full disclosure on this issue). The lead's acting abilities also occassionally waiver (thats what happens when you use unknowns in movies) but it's not enough to warrent a big tirade. The story is still entertaining, and the characters do well with what they are given. <br /> <br />Also...there is definitely an abundance of girls running around in their underwear, so men shouldn't be complaining so much. <br /> <br />Bottom line, this movie is definitely worth checking out for it's awesome special effects, wicked cool music score, great eye candy, and intricate mythologically based storyline.
0618680004|3.0|This is the first Dawkins book I have \\"read\\".  Actually, I listened to it in the six-CD audiobook version.  I highly recommend encountering Dawkins in the audio format - his words themselves are funny, intelligent, informed, and confident, but having his own even, British, and amiable voice present them heightens all these dimensions.  Dawkins is witty, and can be laugh-out-loud funny when pointing out the absurdities of unempirical beliefs when juxtaposed to his deadpan-yet-human, evidenced-based reality.  This juxtaposition also works in regard to creating reactions of horror when Dawkins points our attention to the atrocities that religious beliefs have fostered.  However, Dawkins can also come across as condescending, snarky, and insulting.  At one point in the piece he speaks on the evils of the \\"in-group\\" and \\"out-group\\" mentality.  Yet in reading him, I got the sense that if I could not somehow wholly understand and accept his supposedly self-evident take on the origins and processes of life, I was in an ignorant \\"out-group\\" myself.<br /><br />Dawkins does not combat the notion of God which considers God as simply the implicit beauty, structure, and interrelatedness of all things.  This is my idea of God, so from the first few pages, I was \\"out of the boxing ring\\" so to speak.  The agitation Dawkins creates in this book is between those who believe in a personal, material, omniscient presence who takes an active hand in individual and societal human affairs (often leading to bloodshed, rape, and persecution) and the sober, even-minded, rationalist, humanist, ecological-minded followers of science and empirical reality.<br /><br />The title \\"The God Delusion\\" actually only applies to the first three chapters, in which Dawkins tries to show that Intelligent Design theory or chance alone cannot hold up to statistics, evidence, and science as an explanatory measure for the creation of life and dynamic maintenance of life.  In these initial chapters, he postulatesthat a statistically improbable event (only needing to occur once) created life, and that natural selection is the only acceptable way to comprehend how living things came to be (evolved) as they are at present.  For the former assertion, he offers us mathematical probabilities of unfathomable magnitude as an explanation; of a billion-billion planets, the conditions for life as we know it only needed to occur once for life to begin.  Even if the chances for these conditions being met were one-to-one-billion against, there would still be one billion planets on which life occurred.  For the latter, he goes on to state that evidence of evolution can be found throughout all our biological and geological records, and that no irreducibly complex biological organism or apparatus has ever been found, meaning that all documented life at present had prior, less complicated iterations that gradually led up to the present one.<br /><br />While Dawkins has effectively ruled out chance as an explanation, for me, he has not succeeded in ruling out Intelligent Design.  I do not believe in a personal God who created everything from `His' will.  I have nothing vested in whether or not a personal God created things, or if the cause was a combination of naturally occurring and symbiotic processes.  Rather, Dawkins simply just did not do enough to convince me that his own position was unassailably correct.  Instead, he spends the majority of his time here trying to demonstrate how and why his opponents (the Intelligent Design theorists) are wrong.  He asserts that Intelligent Design has failed on a scientific level, that it merely searches for gaps in current scientific understanding to call its domain, that it has tried to foist the burden of proof upon the skeptics rather than provide any evidence itself, that it is a closed door that calls for an arresting of answer-seeking, and that it tries to win out through defaultism where science itself has yet been unable to provide a properanswer.<br /><br />This deriding of Intelligent Design theory - Dawkins' whole argument - occurs within the parameters of science, its methods, and its mindset.  Dawkins is utterly incapable of accepting any mysticism or supernatural phenomenon on any level.  Everything must be able to be dissected by our instruments.  He hypothesizes that our ability to understand may be \\"limitless\\"; we must simply keep searching.  Dawkins claims himself free of dogma, yet he stands entrenched in the belief that everything can be revealed to our senses if we take the proper approach, give it enough time and thought, and have the proper instruments.<br /><br />This immutability of position is indeed dogmatic.  Dawkins does concede that he will change his position when evidence of an irreducibly complex biological mechanism is found.  Yet in making this concession, he has hypocritically made use of the same reverse burden-of-proof tactic he accuses the Intelligent Design theorists of using.  In effect, he has said:  \\"Everything is understandable.  I cannot prove this because we cannot understand everything, and we have not even discovered everything there is to understand or not understand, but the burden-of-proof lies on the skeptics to find something that can never be understood.\\"  This is not a real quote; it is a hypothetical, and is in the same vein as the hypothetical quotes Dawkins' uses in this book to make his opponents appear foolish.  However, it does accurately represent the spirit of Dawkins' own reversal of the burden-of-proof.  Shouldn't the burden be on science to prove that everything is understandable by understanding everything?  Of course this is silly; yet this is the type of argument Dawkins uses over and over to win us to his side.<br /><br />I personally feel that we passively receive certain experiences that are irreducibly complex, infinite and immeasurable, including love, intuition, purpose and inspiration (not to say that a personal God is behind them, but instead the God of interrelatedness).  Perhaps I am wrong; perhaps someday, the very final mystery will be solved, and the everything of everything will be known to us through assiduous scientific achievement.  Perhaps this is beside the point.  The point is that while Dawkins is capable of deriding the Intelligent Design viewpoint for failing almost every test of sober scientific rigor, he fails in thoroughly convincing me of accepting his own paradigm wholesale.  What he does certainly succeed in, however, is making me feel inadequate for being unable to do so.<br /><br />The final (majority) of the book is not dedicated to scientifically disproving the existence of a personal God, but rather, on musings of the negative effect of dogmatic belief (as seen in religiously-spurred rape, war, human sacrifice, murder, and us-vs.-them mentality), on proving that morality does not come from scripture and can indeed exist without religion, and otherwise further deriding those who are religious.  This section comes across as superfluous in relation to the unfinished job of the first chapters.  In failing to completely depose Intelligent Design (and therefore the morality and meaning-making constructs of a personal God) earlier, these later chapters cannot properly enthrone replacement paradigms for them.  Without fully disproving Intelligent Design, Dawkins cannot completely rend morality and meaning from God either.<br /><br />In this later section, I caught Dawkins more than once resorting to the same pseudo-scientific approach he so rails his opponents for; he hand-picks small samples to represent religious folks in a negative light, while implicitly, and sometimes explicitly, placing atheists outside of such evil, malicious ignorance; he often speculates, sometimes even admitting he did not do any statistical work beforehand, prefacing statements with phrases such as \\"I'll wager\\", and so on.  Once he has placed himself on a podium of logic, sobriety, realism and rationality in the first half of the book (on the bedrock of science), he is free to pontificate as he sees fit in the second half, wearing the badge of the expert, but with the bedrock inexplicably missing.<br /><br />This work must be taken more as a scientifically-informed opinion piece rather than a book of hard scientific fact.  It is highly entertaining, and it is a stunning work of how to present an argument meant to win others over to one's own side.  Dawkins is very educated, charismatic, intelligent, and well-meaning.  Yet it seems where he cannot win us with the facts (which is certainly how he would prefer to win us, and the means through which he does for the most part), he resorts to implicit psychological trickery (a skill at which all charismatic debaters are so adept) and statistical sleight-of-hand (relying on heuristics, hand-chosen examples and case studies, anecdotal evidence, etc.).  For all its faults, however, the book did get me thinking, and energized me to write this review.  In this manner it is very worthwhile - Dawkins, in all his aplomb and scathing wit, strikes me as the type of polarizing figure you either love or hate.  After another book or two of his, I will decide into which camp I fall.<br /><br />And then I will wage an ideological war on the other group.
0843178450|5.0|I used to read these books when I was younger. There's an entire series of them and they are all perfect for kids. The illustrations are colorful and fun and the stories are cute and send good messages. I would read these now, as an 18 year old!
B000BTC5LW|5.0|As great as the Pulse performance is, you wonder what a filming of the 1977 Animals tour could have yielded, when the original lineup was still in full creative force (By the time of The Wall, it was already crumbling).     Make no mistake, The Division Bell is an outstanding album, and Floyd does a phenomonal job of synching the musical performance with the accompanying film (can anyone explain to me how they do this?).  I can't help but wonder how much greater it could have all been had David Gilmour and Roger Waters put aside their egos and issues, and continued to make the greatest music of the latter quarter of the twentieth century.  What incredible stuff would they have created?  It boggles the soul.
B000HT386M|3.0|As is often the case these days, movies like CLICK are often promoted in ad spots by using some of their funniest bits.  If one watches the trailer for this movie one would assume that the plot would be rife with the usual predictable, though funny, stuff: stop-action with Adam Sandler making adjustments to achieve the usual mischief.  Unfortunately the best shtick is wasted in the promos.<br /><br />What actually emerges is a very interesting and serious movie about a man who, wanting to adjust his reality, discovers that things as they are aren't really that bad.  Christopher Walken plays an angel that shows the facts to Sandler's character.  What if things were different? What if you could fast forward through the bad and keep the good?  What if, what if, what if.  Sounds pretty good on the surface.<br /><br />But then something, in my opinion, goes decidedly wrong.  The writers and director decide to pack the film with a bunch of crude and disjointed jokes and themes that keep getting in the way.  Dogs humping legs and stuffed animals and each other may be funny once in a while but when the over-amorous canines go at it again and again and again...well...what the viewer gets is a boring, perverse \\"fake-fingernail-in-the-hamburger\\" experience that really gets in the way. And the canine crazies are the very least of the problems here.  There are plenty of tasteless human anatomical and sexual situations to give the dogs a solid run for the money.<br /><br />The story is wonderful and has a great message but it gets bogged down over and over by the unnecessary nonsense thrown in seemingly because we, the viewers, wouldn't want to see Sandler in a serious role.<br /><br />If you can find this one in some edited form, with all the crude and rude stuff appropriately excised do it.  Otherwise be prepared to wade through a lot of stuff that dilutes and diminishes the beauty of the story. Three stars (and that's being very generous) for the good that's there.<br /><br />THE HORSEMAN/> <br />THE HORSEMAN

B000JBXXZ4|4.0|The first couple of listens really didn't do it for me, but I've come to love this album.  It's not perfect, as the lyrics (though clearly sincere) are just a bit too cliche or corny at times, which results in one guilty pleasure, the immensely catchy \\"Dig,\\" as well as a complete throw-away, the surprisingly bad \\"Love Hurts.\\"  To open the alubm, \\"Quicksand\\" also has some dumb lyrics (\\"Some people fall in love and touch the sky, some people fall in love and find quicksand, I am somewhere in between\\"), but is atmospheric, Radiohead-ish even.  The triptych of the funky \\"A Kiss to Send Us Off,\\" aforementioned \\"Dig,\\" and supremely heavy and groovy \\"Anna Molly\\" is fantastic, then \\"Love Hurts\\" drags before \\"Light Grenades\\" rocks with reckless abandon which almost feels out of place at this point in the album.  A complete shift occurs with \\"Earth to Bella (Part I),\\" a touching ballad which morphs into an awesome jam (good lyrics here and great vocals too, as well as on Part II).  Then, two nice little pop songs in \\"Oil and Water\\" and \\"Diamonds and Coal\\" come in, and they both show evidence of musical maurity. \\"Rogues\\" blasts off next, and it's another winning rocker.  \\"Paper Shoes\\" is another ballad, but the tone explored in the music is further evidence of some musical growth and experimentation and fits the lyrics beautifully.  The album closes a little abruptly with \\"Pendulous Threads\\" and \\"Earth to Bella (Part II).\\"  The former is perhaps the most immediately catchy rocker on the album, even if it is just a little too similar at times lyrically to \\"Undone\\" by Weezer, while the latter is a continuation of the first part and is great, but as I wrote before, ends the album a bit abruptly. All in all, however, a mostly well-paced album, with really only one outright bad song (which is true of every Incubus album).  The leaps and bounds here aren't as significant as those taken on \\"A Crow Left of the Murder,\\" but they're just as rewarding.  The basic themes of this album arebrighter than the last one, and as a result, the musical shift is toward poppier material, which might alienate the fans who miss the rap-metal (I'm not one of them).  Still, this is a fantastic, interesting release from a band that's only getting better with time.

0743298020|5.0|Steeped in the Brontes, DuMaurier, Wilkie Collins, and The Turn of the Screw, this book is at once a throwback to the 19th century and a thoroughly modern reinvention of the gothic story. Setterfield lovingly lifts generic tropes from these classic tales while weaving a story that is utterly hypnotizing and deeply human. <br /> <br />At heart, this is a book about a fictional famous author, and Setterfield evokes a sense of yearning for these nonexistent works. I found myself wishing I could go to the library and dive into Miss Winter's reportedly vast oeuvre, imagining that she'd be a British version of Shirley Jackson, or a slightly domesticated Patricia Highsmith. Setterfield sustains this tension without letting it overwhelm the book, and delivers a payoff that is surprising and satisfying. <br /> <br />Above all, this is a book suffused with the distinct pleasures of reading. I was won completely on page 32. I read this passage and thought, \\"Oh, she knows!\\" <br /> <br />    \\"Of course, one always hopes for something special when one reads an author one hasn't read before, and Miss Winter's books gave me the same thrill I had when I discovered the Landier diaries, for instance. But it was more than that. I have always been a reader; I have read at every stage of my life, and there has never been a time when reading was not my greatest joy. And yet I cannot pretend that the reading I have done in my adult years matches in its impact on my sould the reading I did as a child. I still believe in stories. I still forget myself when I am in the middle of a good book. Yet it is not the same. Books are, for me, it must be said, the most important thing; what I cannot forget is that there was a time when they were at once more banal and more essential than that. When I was a child, books were everything. And so there is in me, always, a nostalgic yearning for the lost pleasure of books. It is not a yearning that one ever expects to be fulfilled. And during this time, these days when I read all day and half the night, when I slept under a counterpane strewn with books, when my sleep was black and dreamless and passed in a flash and I woke to read again-the lost joys of reading returned to me. Miss Winter restored to me the virginal qualities of the novice reader, and then with her stories she ravished me.\\" <br /> <br />I know what she means. Nothing will ever be for me what it was to read Rebecca when I was a lonely middle-schooler, reading it over and over because I needed to know that being alone was something that could be borne. If Mrs. de Winter could survive Manderley, then I could survive seventh grade. <br /> <br />Another such book was Edith Hamilton's Mythology. I still have my copy that I read to death in elementary school, missing front and back cover and most of the spine, and when I pick it up I can't read it properly, because the words knit the stories into my head. The most haunting part for me was her transition from the Greeks and Romans to the Norse. With a few simple sentence she conjured for me the reality of mortality, something that I knew that I didn't want to know, but couldn't stay away. My affinity for this book took me to the point of hiding it from myself. I was so enraptured by the stories that I wondered in earnest if I was hurting Jesus's feelings by reading them, and so I put them away. <br /> <br />Tom Robbins once said that all smokers are Prometheus, and I say that all readers are Pandora. I think Setterfield would agree with me, and I'm pleased to let her know that she might not have given me Vida Winter's books, but she gave me what Margaret Lea found in them-a read that stopped time.

0517548232|1.0|Probably one of the more blatantly biased books I've ever read. Should be renamed \\"Libertarians are Cool.\\" Yes, libertarianism is the foundation of modern economics and seems sensible. But this book is basically a libertarian manifesto shouted really loudly, with no objective evaluation in sight. It is NOT adequate substitution for an economics course, as I hoped it would be. <br /> <br />The claim on the back of the book that it is written \\"objectively and impartially\\" is completely ridiculous; Hazlitt's approach is inflammatory and dogmatic. He compares taxes to \\"being robbed\\" (96), compares fixed prices to \\"coercions\\" (116), goes off on melodramatic tangents about evil government controls leading to \\"final abandonment of all the traditional liberties we have known\\" (123), and basically characterizes any government official as wicked and intending to steal from the masses and head towards \\"the seeds of fascism and communism\\" (176). Straight out of the cold war. <br /> <br />What is peculiar is the fact that he does indeed concede that certain services should be paid with taxes (police, roads, etc.). Why can't those be private too? These implications of Hazlitt's libertarian theories are not explored; they are merely mentioned in apologetic passing. If taxes really are just a power trip, why have them at all? This question remains unanswered. <br /> <br />Also, Hazlitt doesn't realize that his claims apply to things that he says, not just other people's purported \\"foolery.\\" He doesn't mind \\"Industry X\\" dying because it will \\"release the necessary capital and labor for the new industries\\" (102), but then gets all bent out of shape when another Industry X goes out of business due to minimum wage laws (136) by pointing out the resulting \\"unemployment.\\"  Why is unemployment bad here, but okay before?  He excuses unemployment in the first case as \\"necessary\\" and then calls out the second instance as \\"condemning the people who worked in that industry\\" (136).  Which one is it?  His decision to hide or showcase negative evidence rests solely on convenience, not truth. <br /> <br />Read something else.
B000092Q8C|3.0|As other reviewers have noted, this is not multichannel or multiformat.  What this means is that it will only play in a SACD player, and only the Left and Right channels are active in an SACD direct 6-channel connection.  No subwoofer, no surrounds, etc. It can be played from an SACD player through a standard analog/digital connection and allow the receiver to add sound processing (dolby, dts, etc) for all channel playback.  It won't play in a standard CD player or computer.   <br /> <br />However, the sound quality could only improve for me as my previous copy is on vinyl (yikes!).  Maybe a full SACD version will come someday . . .

B000I0QKDS|5.0|When I was a younger guy, worshipping at the temple of Aerosmith and Joe Perry, hungrily devouring every little snippet of info about them, I would always come across Perry's idoltry of Jeff Beck and how influential Beck and the Yardbirds (among others obviously) were to his sound and devotion to music. Like any good history student, I did some research and came across a double lp of this album and the follow-up Beck-Ola. It didn't take long to figure out what all the fuss was about.<br /><br />This is a Beck tour de force from the simple elegance of Greensleeves to the galloping intensity of Beck's Bolero, the sheer sickness of You Shook Me, and the blues workouts on Blues De Luxe, Let Me Love You, Rock My Plimsoul, and I Ain't Superstitious, this is a lethal collection of Beck's genius and guitar mastery. The bonus edition was worth replacing my old cd with because of the rarity of Beck outtakes and the frank commentary provided by the man himself in the liner notes. I know some have slagged it off, but I really enjoy the cheesy Love is Blue most of all!<br /><br />The man is one of a handful of guitarists from the rock world to have influenced guitarists across the genres and his refusal to go quietly into that good night of laurel resting, blues retreading, or commercial banality, proves more and more that Jeff Beck remains as fresh and vital as he did in his groundbreaking days over four decades ago. If you really want to know why this guy is (or should be) mentioned in the same breath as Jimi Hendrix, give this a listen. Thanks for the tip, Joe Perry.
B00000F1D3|4.0|Cher has been around for quite a long time and garnered nearly every major award out there.  For someone of her age at the time of Believe's release it's hard to see how she could have been so successful since this CD is dance pop--then again, she's Cher.  The title track scored her another international No. 1 hit single and shot the album to the top of the charts, selling millions and millions of copies.  So is Believe worth all the hype?  Yes, and no.  \\"Believe\\" the song is brilliant disco-infused dance pop and any singer could have easily topped the charts with it had it not been given to Cher.  The rest of the album follows suit, delivering catchy dance pop that would easily fit into the Top 40 mold of 1998 when it was first released.  Unfortunately, it gets cheesy as you get further into the meat, and the fact Cher's well above the age of dance pop makes the album sound a bit immature.  Still, Cher's throaty voice sounds great here and song-for-song it is one of her best records.

These stories all have potential, but only Hook Man lives up to it. The two brothers alternate between knowing everything and knowing nothing. And could someone please decide which brother is supposed to be the expert? In episodes 1 and 2 it seems to be Dean, but after that it's Sam. Then there's the problem of exposition, handled here with all the skill of a team of eight-year-olds. The brothers are constantly telling each other things they already know just so the audience can get the background information. Most of what they explain we already know or don't need to know. \\"Have you noticed anything strange?\\" Sam says in every episode, then adds, \\"anything out of the ordinary?\\" just to make sure we knew what he meant by strange.  <br /> <br />The plot inconsistencies make it difficult to sit through an episode without turning into Crow or Tom Servo fromMST3K and offering a few choice comments: spiders and earthworms are NOT bugs! And what are all those hissing cockroaches doing in that kid's back yard? Aren't they mostly found in Madagascar? 0061191752|4.0|I've been a massive Gordon Ramsay fan since the first time I glimpsed him on BBC America, then came Hell's Kitchen and Kitchen Nightmares to feed my obsession.  I purchased two of his cookbooks for my friend for Christmas and as we were exchanging gifts it turned out that she had done the same.  Secretly I purchased Roasting in Hell's Kitchen all for myself and read it cover to cover the day after Christmas. <br /> <br />Having just finished watching the first run of the F-Word on BBC America (because everything comes over here a year late at least from the BBC) I was expecting lots of dish on his television ventures and his rise to culinary stardom.  This book completely surprised and enthralled me.  If there was a ghost writer for this book I'd be gobsmacked, as the writing style is completely in keeping with the way Gordon talks about things in his cook books and on his television shows, no holds are barred and no f-word gets left behind.  It is a rare auto-biography that is penned so true to it's author's voice and raw with authenticity. <br /> <br />I had no idea that this brash, confident, gorgeous man in the kitchen who is so engaging and fun has had so much to overcome and in such a short amount of time.  One might think that reading 300 pages of heartbreak, abuse and grueling work (nothing short of a Dickensian tale) would change the way I look at a person, and truthfully it has.  I'm even more impressed and amazed by Gordon Ramsay now than ever. <br /> <br />His story is one that took immense amounts of bravery and bullocks to tell, and he has done so in a way that is astoundingly heartfelt and never hopeless.  Gordon's incredibly recent bout with success is well deserved and I hope it lasts long enough to provide material for additional updates on his fascinating life.

I hear people say this about books all the time, but I've never truly experienced it.<br /><br />This book began near the end of the actual story being told, and through a series of flash-backs relays a story that is so tragically heart-wrenching that I soon found myself addicted.<br /><br />The reason that I couldn't stop reading was that because of the way the book was set up, I already knew how it ended; it was just a matter of finding out why and how. B000JJS8TM|4.0|For those of us who love The Beatles but also appreciate good sound quality, this two disc re-mix is a treat. One of the discs is on DVD and this format is outstanding for music. The DVD offers 4 separate mixes. One in surround sound DVD Audio, and you must have the proper set up to play this. There are also two other surround sound mixes, DTS and DD 5.1, plus an excellent PCM Stereo mix. All of these are recorded in a higher bit rate than the original mixes and therefore have excellent sound. Technically, the DVD Audio 5.1 mix should be the best, but on my system the vocals are mixed too loud in the center channel and I actually prefer the DTS and Dolby Digital 5.1 surround sound mixes. I also love the stereo mix on the DVD. If you have a surround sound speaker setup and receiver, but not a DVD Audio player, but this 2-disc set anyway and play the other mixes on the DVD, you'll love it. As one reviewer mentioned, if you have DVD Audio, when you insert this disc it defaults to DVD Audio and doesn't give you the menu so you can select one of the other mixes. Go into your DVD system set up menu and switch the DVD VIDEO to DVD VIDEO instead of DVD AUDIO and then try again, and you'll get the menu so you can select the other 3 mixes. I would've rated it 5 stars if not for this glitch. Now let's hope that they come out with the entire Beatles catalog on DVD Audio or Super Audio with both surround sound and stereo remixes in the better quality. One last note on SACD compared to DVD AUDIO. Super Audio CDs don't have anywhere near the capacity as DVDs. I have both types and although both sound great, DVD AUDIO is best because there's room for several mixes plus on-screen graphics. Simply put, DVD is an outstanding format for both music and video. Can't be beat. Most of the big names like Elton John, the Stones, Dylan, are on SACD however.

B000068IEU|3.0|Last House on the Left... wow. Pretty strange. First off, let me say, without reservation, that horror is my genre of choice. I pretty much dig everything from the supernatural, to thrillers, to straight splatter fests. I'm fan of other W. Craven films as well... the Elm St. series, the Hills Have Eyes, Scream, etc. So it was with high hopes that I read the bulk of the reviews of 'Last House,' which painted the picture of some sort of brutal shock-fest filled with disturbing scenes of violence.    Yeah, well, that didn't happen.     To begin with, there is very little actual violence depicted on screen- for the most part you just hear sounds, see blood after the fact, etc. True, the subject matter is disturbing, but no more so than what you are likely to see on the nightly news on any given day. I knew, intellectually, that I was supposed to be frightened and/or disturbed, but as I watched it, I actually found myself laughing out loud. I felt like Michael Keaton in Beetlejuice, when he tells Alec Baldwin, \\"I've see the Exorcist 167 times and it keeps getting funnier every single time!\\"    Now, the acting is fine and the film definitely looks good (very grainy, like an old home movie, with some evocative landscape shots of the rural North East), but it is hard to get past the over the top, \\"straight outta Brooklyn\\" killers. They really do come off like the Bizarro World doppelgangers of Vinnie Barbarino and his Sweathogs from 'Welcome Back Kotter.' They were, in fact, almost impossible to take seriously, especially in conjunction with the INSANE musical score.    Actually, the score deserves special mention. I don't know if Craven was trying to be ironic, or just plain weird, but the music is wildly incongruous, with regard to the action in the film. In scenes involving rape, mutilation, and fleeing for one's life while covered in blood, the score ranges from troubador-style, acoustic folk ballads to upbeat, vaguely psychedelic instrumental pieces that sound more like music you would hear at a carnival (the friendly, cotton candy sort, not the Something Wicked This Way Comes variety) than as the backdrop to a murder. As the killers are in the midst of their spree I kept turning to my fiancee, who had seen the movie before, with confused questions like \\"Is this music supposed to be making me laugh?\\"     (spoilers below)    Then there was the end of the film. The parents, through some fortuitous observations, surmise that their house guests killed their missing daughter something like ten minutes earlier and so set about taking their revenge. Within the space of minutes, the bereaved mother is, err... going downtown with one of the killers, if you catch my drift, whereupon she quite literally bites off more than she can chew. I guess that falls somewhere between \\"anger\\" and \\"bargaining\\" in the five stages of grief... Then the father is setting traps like MacGyver and taking a chainsaw to people as though he had been carving human cutlets all his life. The only logical response to this improbable insanity was laughter- as I said in the title to this review, 'twas mighty odd. Of course, it entertained me enough to watch through till the end, so I have to give it three stars, with the caveat that this is strictly dark comedy material, with elements of true horror being few and far between. If you are looking for an unsettling, gritty, and morally ambiguous descent into human depravity, you would be much better off watching The Devil's Rejects or Hostel. Last House on the Left is better suited to MST3000-style parody, which can be quite fun in it's own right, but won't exactly keep you up at night.

There is a certain authority that Liebovitz brings to her journalistic photos.  But this book is mostly not these portraits.
