B00005NTJK|5.0|Jethro Tull suffers an undeserved low esteem in the pop music scene nowadays (That is, here in the U.S.), in good part because of the vice of not pretending to be the least bit lowbrow.  Not to say that they are particularly highbrow, but they are intelligent, English, well-read, and skillful, all of which are generally undesirable in the pop music and media scene in general, at least in record and video stores.  They even use the word \\"whom\\" in one of these songs!    That faux-pas notwithstanding, this is to me their best offering.  It is certainly the one that really launched them on a successful career in the 20th C, and their songs range from heavy and fateful, to gentle and tender.  They were the kind of band that usually was listened to by the college set in the 70's and 80's, and not appreciated as much elsewhere.     There was a movement among a lot of rock musicians back then to prove to the world that they actually posessed skills that could rival traditional \\"classical\\" music, exemplified by Yes, Kansas, ELO, and maybe best by Rick Wakeman.  But Jethro Tull wasn't so allured to try to take on \\"classical\\" music because they could actually play it from the word go.      They would soon develop a penchant for older English folk music, and showed the world they were unashamed anglophiles, thus wrecking their popularity here in the U.S., who were still trying to get over the American revolution.  But this penchant hadn't yet begun to develop, and this early album was a genuine collection of sincere, simple rock music played with more skill and elegance than was found very often in this time period.  Five stars.
0671027344|1.0|I hate to say it but I really felt this book was a waste of a perfectly good title, format, and idea.  I was very eager to read The Perks of Being a Wallflower after four friends recommended it, even after noticing it was an MTV book and recognizing that these friends rarely picked up a book that was for outside reading.<br /><br />It starts out good.  Charlie is likable and his commentary is interesting and inadvertently humorous.  As the story progressed, however, it seemed to lose focus and I found myself turning each page thinking \\"Okay, maybe now it will get better\\" but each turn only proved how mistaken I was.<br /><br />Charlie's character goes from realistic kid to the typical angst-ridden teen stereotype that only an adult author, trying to cater to the notions of teenage behavior embedded in pre-teen minds, could write about.  The storyline has too many flaws to remember them all, but here are a few: Charlie's best friend who commited suicide is completely forgotten about with the exception of one line much later in the book.  He falls in with a huge group of seniors at the head of the party scene, tries every kind of beer and illegal substance on the market, and has multiple sexual interactions with two senior girls.  Sorry, but I find it an insult that this type of person would ever be classified as a \\"wallflower.\\"  His sister is a joke of a character whose actions make little sense, and the twist in the end isn't so much a twist as a means of just giving the story an ending without needing to really justify it.  I really doubt Chbosky could have done much research on that subject with the way he wrote it.<br /><br />I would only recommend this book as an example of a story that had an immense amount of potential but did not result in a work of good literature.  Very disappointing, because I thought Chbosky had a good writing style too.

The film and the accompanying soundtrack were huge hits, hitting number one at the box office and topping the billboard charts. Career-wise Barbra never looked back. She successfully starred in and executive-produced a box office smash, something unheard of in the 1970s for a woman, and it was from the strength of this film that she went on to direct and star in the critically acclaimed films Yentl and the Prince of Tides.  <br /> <br />Instead of looking at the merits of the film, some reviews here suggest the clothes and hairstyles in A Star Is Born are dated. If you are looking to see one of the biggest hits of the 1970s, watch A Star Is Born. Barbra won an Oscar and two Grammy awards for composing/singing the (Love theme from A Star Is Born) Evergreen.  She also took home Golden Globes for acting, composing and producing.

If we have mystical experiences and try to understand them (not pronounce them as dogma); if we can look at the myths that carry spiritual and psychological wisdom (and not make a religion of them)--it is a rational enterprize. Right-on, Sam Harris.
B000ICL3KG|3.0|Having finally gotten around to seeing Al Gore's global warming film, I came away thinking it is being overpraised.<br /><br />This being a film, the science had to be simplified due to time constraints. That's always true. But Gore simplifies by ignoring important points. To him, all recent warming of the Earth is human-caused. No time is spent on the important issue of how much of the measured warming can definitely be ascribed to human actions and how much is normal long-term change expected for a planet in an interglacial warm period.<br /><br />The visual effects are mostly effective, even if some (like the drowning of Manhattan) illustrate \\"worst case\\" scenarios that Gore presents as likely, if not certain. Gore blames Hurricane Katrina on human-caused warming, which is hardly established fact. (If he is going to use the bad hurricane year of 2005 as evidence of long-term change, one wonders what he has to say now about very weak 2006 season.)  In a litany of side effects of warming, he includes the emergence of drug-resistant tuberculosis. (Huh?)<br /><br />While Gore mainly points the finger at the U.S., he does a good job of making it clear the situation is global by spending some time on the contribution to greenhouse gases made by China's rapid population and economic expansion.<br /><br />At one point, Gore throws out a very important statement that needs support. He says that if we \\"do the right thing\\" (changing energy technologies, ending greenhouse gas emissions) we will \\"create new wealth and jobs.\\" That may be true, but it requires explanation, especially when not a word is said about the technical and economic challenges involved in changing over from fossil to renewable energy. (I agree we have to make a major start on this, and quickly, but it will not be easy or cheap, and Gore should be upfront about that.)<br /><br /> As a movie, the film meanders. Detours on Gore's personal life and political experiences make the viewer suspect this is a bit of a campaign commercial as well as an environmental film. There are bits that don't make sense (the weird Simpson-ish animation near the beginning, for example) and could have been replaced with more scientific information.<br /><br />Overall, Gore set out to make a point here, and he generally does it well. He's become more relaxed and engaging than he was as a candidate, although my 10-year-old (who watched with me for a school assignment) still compared him to a \\"really boring teacher.\\" Still, there is too much oversimplification and overstatement involved in driving the point home. Gore leaves himself open to criticism, some of it accurate, that could have been avoided if the film spent more time on the science of the core subject and less on everything from Gore family farm to non-warming-related extinctions.<br /><br />So see the film, but don't take it as the whole story of a complex subject.as well as an environmental film. There are bits that don't make sense (the weird Simpson-ish animation near the beginning, for example) and could have been replaced with more scientific information. <br /> <br />Overall, Gore set out to make a point here, and he generally does it well. He's become more relaxed and engaging than he was as a candidate, although my 10-year-old (who watched with me for a school assignment) still compared him to a \\"really boring teacher.\\" Still, there is too much oversimplification and overstatement involved in driving the point home. Gore leaves himself open to criticism, some of it accurate, that could have been avoided if the film spent more time on the science of the core subject and less on everything from Gore family farm to non-warming-related extinctions. <br />So see the film, but don't take it as the whole story of a complex subject.

However, nowhere in his book does he make it clear that he is skeptical researcher. B00004Y6OA|5.0|There are three Van Halen incarnations, the original line-up with David Lee Roth, the Sammy Hagar era, and the one shot with Gary Cherone, \\"Van Halen III\\", which was a disaster.<br /><br />  It's disheartening to see a band that broke so many rules in its DLR heyday flounder to the unemployed ranks they are today, but that's the price they paid when Roth was fired or quit, depending on whose story you believe.<br /><br />  But let's face it:  Van Halen had four great albums, the first four.  \\"Diver Down\\" and \\"1984\\" were watered down with too many covers - \\"Diver Down\\", and pop schmaltz - \\"1984\\", not to mention the most horrible production for a major league band ever.  No wonder Roth left.<br /><br />  \\"Women And Children First\\" could lay a fair claim to the first thrash metal album or bonecrusher ala Pantera, however you choose.  \\"And The Cradle Will Rock\\" starts the CD out in familiar enough territory, with Dave's smug but clever vocals and Eddie's tapping, but that's where any resemblance to the first two outings ends.  \\"Everybody Wants Some!\\" is the threshold heavy rock had to cross to go into uncharted waters, redefining the very genre of metal with Eddie's brutal attack chords and Armegeddon whammy dives.  The assault continues all the way through \\"Take Your Whiskey Home\\", then cools down for the stoopid title track (which we could have done without) and the closer \\"In A Simple Rhyme\\" that probably would have been better placed on the first album with its harmonies, but that's okay.  We had to come up for air.<br /><br />  What made Van Halen's first albums special was Roth's bigger than life stage presence, lyrics that often bordered on stupid but were clever enough to give the band an edge that showed it was in on the joke, too.<br /><br />  There can be no comparison to the insultingly horrible Sammy Hagar-led line-up.  The music was atrocious, and Hagar tried to equate himself as funny and smart as Roth, and only came off as the bumbling stooge he is.  Roth got away with sexism through implication and humor.  Hagar, referring to women as cuts of beef on \\"5150\\" showed about as much intelligence and humor as a dead cactus.  Ditto the remarkably stupid album titles that followed, and a once cutting edge band became as banal as Hagar's love for Rush Limbaugh.<br /><br />  For a while, though, they were the best in hard rock, and maybe if Roth rejoins, as the rumors persist, we might just get a taste of what made them special in the first place.  Meanwhile, get the first four CD's and hound somebody to remaster them.th got away with sexism through implication and humor. Meanwhile, get the first four CD's and hound somebody to remaster them.
B00000JPH0|4.0|Any work of art must address the three aspects of our psyche: Intellect, Appetites, Spirit.  This movie, unlike many others, addresses the entire psyche, and does so by weaving these three aspects through the soundtrack, the dialogue and of course the visual representation.  After the first viewing, the actual historical account is told and the psyche is no longer overburdened with the obvious.  Later viewings allow for a much more meaningful experience.  In this, I believe that the production staff have succeeded in their task.<br /><br />Finland being the underdog, does successfully thwart the massive Russian attack.  Not being the aggressor and losing the advantage of first attack, Finland must respond to this attack of its country.  But it is not a superior technology, nor numbers that is responsible for this victory of sorts.  It is the spirit of man that allows for this page of World War II history to come alive, and if there is anything good from war, it is the ability for men and women to show the eternal and noble virtues within in each of us.<br /><br />I was not born in Finland, but my parents were, and did raise me with more of a European background than Canadian.  With some grade school level Finnish fluency, I found the subtitles to be mildly off target, but then again, there might be some disagreement in my interpretation too.  While I would agree with other reviewers that sometimes it is difficult to read all of the subtitles, I am reminded by the fact that this movie was produced a number of years ago.  I think that the movie can hardly be held to critical review for technical issues that were resolved after its production.<br /><br />There is a word in Finnish, SISU, which has no English counterpart or translation.  This movie while a wonderful rendering of this historic event, does in passing allow the non-Finnish speaking person a chance to understand what Finns mean by it.<br /><br />I would heartily suggest this movie for its edu-tainment purposes, but if a History teacher were looking for something to engage children, this movie could very well do so. B000H7JD4A|4.0|Ever since the release of \\"Seventh Son of a Seventh Son\\", Maiden has been a bit unpredictable. \\"No Prayer for Dying\\" and \\"Fear of the Dark\\" where clearly inferior in quality (and production) to Maiden's prior efforts. \\"The X Factor\\" took a totally different direction from the stripped down - back to the roots approach from it's two predecessors and was a very dark and mellow album that was rejected by many fans (though I personally think it was a solid album), and with \\"Virtual XII\\", Maiden attempted to go back to a more \\"Maiden\\" sound, though the album was brought down by bad production, bad vocals, and overall bad song-writing and is easily Maiden's worst album (even so, it still has a couple tracks that where very good). So, Blaze leaves, and Bruce Dickinson (along with Adrian Smith) are back in the fold, and Maiden releases \\"Brave New World\\", which was a very safe album with the same approach as Virtual XII, but with much better songwriting, production, and Bruce Dickinson on vocals. Then came \\"Dance of Death\\", which was more experimental, with songs like \\"Face in the Sand\\" and \\"Journeyman\\", which are a bit unorthodox by Maiden standards. The album was half killer/half filler (though the killer songs such as \\"Paschendale\\" and \\"Rainmaker\\" where very good). So the next step in the evolution is \\"A Matter of Life and Death\\"....    In \\"A Matter of Life and Death\\", most of the elements from recent Maiden albums are present, but it finally clicks. The slow, gloomy intro's and war-themed lyrics from \\"The X Factor\\" are present. The more up-beat, vintage Maiden approach from \\"Virtual XII\\" (though it failed in that album) and \\"Brave New World\\" are present, and the more experimental approach from \\"Dance of Death\\" is present as well.     \\"A Matter of Life and Death's\\" biggest strenth is the fact that it is a very solid album. There isn't a song that you can point at and classify as a clear filler (which unfortunately, there has been an abundance of those in the last 16 yearsfrom Maiden). Every song fits each other like a glove, and the album (for the most part) revolves around the themes of war and religion.    The album kicks off with the hard-rocking \\"Different World\\", which is a nice, fast rocker with good lyrics, and a great solo from Adrian Smith. \\"These Colours Don't Run\\" follows the recent trend of having a slow intro, though it works good  in this case, as the soft guitar harmony over the clean guitars sounds very good, which eventually lead up to a good guitar riff and an interesting verse, though the chorus sounds a bit out of place, in which Bruce sounds a bit strained. To me, \\"These Colours Don't Run\\" is the worst song on the album, yet, it's by no means a filler and it's still a good track. Then comes \\"Brither than a Thousand Suns\\", which is one of the highlights of the album. It's very heavy by Maiden standards. The song conitunes at a steady mid-tempo pace, then Adrian Smith ripps a very good guitar solo, one of his best since re-joining the band, which is followed by sweet vintage maiden guitar galloping in vein of The Trooper, which is followed by a great guitar solo by Janick Gers. \\"The Pilgrim\\" is a mid-tempo tune just over 5 minutes long with a nice eastern flavor to it. The song isn't anything special, but it serves it's purpose as a rather short, cathcy tune in an album full of epics. \\"The Longest Day\\" is another strong song. The gory imagery portrayed in the verse is very memorable, and the bridge and chorus are very catchy. \\"The Longest Day\\" also has very good guitar solos and harmonies that compliment the song nicely, making it one of the highlights from the album. Next in line is \\"Out of the Shadows\\", which would easily fit in into one of Bruce Dickinson's solo albums. The song has some clean rhythm guitars with great singing from Bruce Dickinson with scattered guitar leads throughout the song and some great lyrics. \\"Out of the Shadows\\" is one of my personal favorites from the album, and I wish Maiden would steer into the direction of this song a bit more for future albums. So, after a nice, soft mellow song, we get \\"The Reincarnation of Benjamin Breeg\\", which after a mellow intro, is driven by a very heavy and catchy guitar riff. The vocal lines aren't anything special, though the breakdown and riffs, followed by a descent guitar solo from Dave Murray makes this song interesting. Then comes \\"For the Greater Good of God\\", the big epic, written solely by Steve Harris. The lyrics are very good and interesting, with a good chorus and good guitar solos by the trio. Though \\"For the Greater Good of God\\" is lacking a good guitar lick or a little something in the first few minutes of the song, the interesting lyrics and instrumental section definetaly elevates this song in quaility. The following track, \\"Lord of Light\\" starts out very slow and dark as Bruce almost whispers the opening lines. The song then turns into a fast and heavy tune highlighted by Bruce's wailing vocals and a fast, heavy, almost thrash metal-like guitar riff. \\"Lord of Light\\" eventually slows down again, and begins to build up, until Adrian Smith comes in and ripps another great solo, leading into the moment where the song shifts up a gear (again) in which Dave Murray delivers his best guitar solo in the album. \\"Lord of Light\\" is a great song, and is my second favorite on the album, second only to the album's closer, \\"The Legacy\\". Perhaps Janick Gers' best composition with Maiden, \\"The Legacy\\" is an exellent track. The acoustic guitars in the intro really adds to the song, which leads to a good guitar riff. However, the song really turns it up a notch at around the 5:35 mark, when a sweet guitar lick kicks in, leading to a great guitar solo from Janick Gers and some very good triple guitar harmonies.     So, the songs are good, how about the production? The previos album \\"Dance  of Death\\" sounded a bit muddy, however, producer Kevin Shirley did a great job with the production. Steve Harris' bass hasn't sounded as good as it sounds on \\"A Matter of Life and Death\\" in a long time.     The musicianship is superb in this album. Adrian is great as always, as is Dave Murray, but (surprisingly to some fans) Janick Gers also has some very good contributions to both the song writing and guitar work. Nicko does gives a solid performance with the drums, adding a bit more groove than in prior albums, and Steve gives his best performance on bass since \\"The X Factor\\". The lyrics in this album are also very good and iteresting. The war theme is present as it is on many Maiden albums, such as in \\"The Longest Day\\" which is about the amphibious-landings on D-Day on the western front in World War II, \\"These Colour's Don't Run\\", which has lyrics about the chivalrious reasons and motivations that drive people to go to war, and \\"For the Greater Good of God\\", which questions the concept of a holy war and really has some great lyrics, especially the line     \\"Please tell me now what life is  Please tell me now what love is  Well tell me now what war is  Again tell me what life is\\"    as it really points out the contradiction of going to war on the basis of religios difference, since most religions claim to be about loving and value life, yet they stand against their teachings when they take people's lifes simply because they believe in something else.    Overall, \\"A Matter of Life and Death\\" is a solid album, and it's easily the best album since 1988's \\"Seventh Son of a Seventh Son\\" (which really isn't saying much considering the quality of some Maiden albums released post-1988). It definetaly is a grower, and might take some people a few listens for the album to sink in. The album isn't nearly on par with such classics such as \\"Piece of Mind\\" and \\"Somewhere in Time\\", but its good nontheless and a very solid release by Iron Maiden, one of ( and in my opinion) the best heavy metal band. I recommend this album.

B000002KIT|5.0|Talking about music is like dancing about architecture, and taste is subjective, but for my money Thin Lizzy was the greatest live overseas band I ever saw, and I saw them many, many times. In a world that still foolishly hails the Stones as the Greatest Rock and Roll Band on Earth, and which still trembles at the supposed greatness of Led Zeppelin (who indeed were great in the studio but were, after their first two tours, simply and consistently GODAWFUL onstage)... revisiting this extraordinary album might bring some justice...    Twin lead guitarists that could match the talents of anyone of their day... Brian Downey, as sharp and driving and inventive a drummer as one can imagine (again, this John Bonham worship is nonsense, I'm sorry friends. Downey could have blown him off the stage.) And finally the much missed Phil Lynott, who besides having a fine voice and a powerful bass hand could write lyrics that could rip your heart out, not just of lost love but of war and legend and madness...)    This is a masterclass of guitar drenched rock reaching it's greatest potential. Rock and roll for adults. It's sad that Lizzy never made a dent in the States (they simply painted with too many colors and couldn't be categorized... hence deer in the headlight looks from critics...)    And if the tragedy of heroin has ever been more nakedly obvious it's in the passing of Mr. Lynott, as fine a poet and eloquent a soul as Ireland has ever produced.     Listen to the words. Then go Dancing in the Moonlight.

B000002QWD|5.0|I found this CD at my local Food Lion for seven dollars - two dollars more than Amazon sells it for. But I'd be happy to pay twice or maybe even three times that much for this wonderful CD. <br /> <br />Sometimes, I feel like I am something of an anomaly of my generation, as I long for things from the days of old along with the current things that are popular. This CD fills my need for classic Christmas music, and makes me nostalgic for a time about 30-40 years before I was even born. <br /> <br />The CD is not perfectly remastered. There's hissing, crackles, and pops - not distracting or loud, but you can tell they're there. It sounds like a CD recorded from a record that's maybe been played once or twice. I like for my classic Christmas music to sound like this. Everything else, I like when it's slightly digitally remastered to take away hisses, crackles, pops, and noise so that you can hear the music, but not remastered to much that it sounds harsh. But for some reason, old Christmas music almost doesn't sound right if it's perfectly clean and clear and crisp. This CD doesn't. It sounds nostalgic. It sounds like old Christmas music should. <br /> <br />The music is extremely well done on this CD. The first half consists of mostly ballads, but very well done ballads, such as Silent Night, I'll Be Home For Christmas, and the classic title track. The second half has more pep, with guest appearances by The Andrews Sisters on three of the tracks - Jingle Bells, Santa Claus Is Coming To Town, (You may recognize these versions from the classic 1983 movie A Christmas Story, where you can hear them in the background of some scenes.) and the Hawaiian-inspired Mele Kalikimaka. Guest vocals are also used on Silver Bells by Carole Richards. <br /> <br />I wholeheartedly recommend this CD to anyone, young or old, who loves Christmas music the way it used to be. I love Christmas music old and new, but I definitely prefer older, more traditionally done Christmas music, and thisCD fits the bill. And it's a steal at the price Amazon is offering it for. You may also be able to find it at one of your local drug stores/grocery stores. It may be a few dollars more than it is here, but it's absolutely worth it.

The rest of the cast all being pros in their own right, as well.<br /><br />  Definitely a must see for lovers of warm, \\"true\\" feeling tales that help us to help ourselves.
0307237699|4.0|Let me begin by saying The Audacity of Hope is a fine book. It is optimistic, inspiring, and it is one I am glad I read. Senator Obama is beyond all doubt a charismatic figure, an intelligent man, a person of integrity and vision. However (yes, you knew there was going to be a \\"however\\") I was surprised that the more I read his book, the more I became unwillingly struck by the fact that this most interesting new figure in American politics almost seems to be trying to found a stance that reaches across to the left and right in a way that perhaps compromises an ability to define himself as anything other than so centrist and moderate he could one day be accused by both conservative and liberal alike of betraying his alleged loyalties to the values he professes. Yes, I found him honest, yes, I found him a welcome alternative to the stagnation in current American politics. His meteoric rise to national prominence is both fascinating and a great latter-day, boundary-shattering success story. I also think his very existence within his party represents a tremendous potential for Democrats to reclaim unfairly lost ground against mendacious Republican foes, but as I said earlier, I kept coming to the conclusion, much to my own consternation, that Senator Obama truly imperils himself in being almost TOO broad-based for real depth. Time will ultimately tell how much of a future this Senator and current popular culture superstar truly has. From his own words, I emerged liking him, but...somehow seeing him as not yet fully evolved or sure of his own views. I wish him luck. I think America needs more good people willing to step forward into public service.
